On the 27th of July, Mr. Liney saw me with the truck, and claimed it—I told him I had bought and paid for it—the prisoner was with the man I bought it of—he was the first who asked me to purchase it—he said it belonged to both of them, that they were in partnership, and were going to leave off partnership—it is the same truck which Liney claims.
JOHN WHITING. I live in Red Lion-street, Clerkenwell—I was with Dumon when he bought the truck—a man who was with the prisoner sold it—I did not hear the prisoner say anything.
Prisoner. He did not give me any money for it. Witness. He gave the other man 27s. for it.
THOMAS SEAVOL (policeman.) I took the prisoner—I have the truck here—Liney has seen it.

GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Confined Two Months.

1899.
ALEXANDER HOWETT and
MARK KINGSTON were indicted for
stealing 7 yards of cotton, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
John Booker and another, and that Kingston had been before convicted of felony.

JOSEPH BOOKER. I am assistant to John Booker, of London-terrace, Hackney-road—he has one partner—these seven yards of printed cotton are their property—on the 2nd of Aug., a little before three in the afternoon,

they were on the rail outside the door—I received information from Mr. Apsall, who lives opposite, about a quarter of an hour after—he brought the prisoner Howett and the cotton to me, and told me, in his presence, that he had found it on him—I asked him how he became possessed of it—he said a young man threw it into his arms—Kingston was brought shortly after—a policeman was sent for, and they were given in charge.

GEORGE APSALL. I live with my father, an upholsterer, at Cambridge-place, Hackney-road, opposite Mr. Booker's—on the 2nd of August, a little before three o'clock in the afternoon, by my father's desire, I watched the prisoners from the front parlour window—they were together—I saw King
ston unpin the piece of cloth at Mr. Booker's shop, and give it to Howett—my father caught Howett, I caught Kingston—I am quite sure he is the man who unpinned it.
WILLIAM FOY (policeman.) I was sent for, and took the prisoners—I told them they must come to the station—they said nothing.
Howett's Defence. The cloth was thrown into my arms.
Kingston's Defence. I know nothing about it.

WILLIAM BEASLEY. I produce a certificate of Kingston's former convic
tion—(read—Convicted, June, 1846, and confined three months)—I was present at the trial—he is the person.

HOWETT—
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months.

KINGSTON—
GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1900.
RICHARD MARTIN was indicted
for embezzlement.

THOMAS HUNT. I am a fishmonger in Fitzroy-market—the prisoner was in my employ for about three months—he ran away at Whitsuntide, the 24th of May, and did not come back—he has received money and brought it to me—I engaged him to deliver fish, and if the bills were paid, he should have brought the money to me—he was not hired as a collector—he has received money before, and paid me—he has not accounted to me for 1l. 2s. 3d., paid by Mary Ann Roon for Mr. Cowling, or for 3s. 6d. from Mr. Hopper.

MARY ANN ROON. I am servant to Mr. Cowling, of Portland-square, Chelsea—I saw my mistress pay the prisoner 1l. 2s. 3d.—she is pregnant, and not able to come here—I saw it paid—I saw silver, a half-sovereign, and some halfpence—I am sure the prisoner is the person—I know that Mr. Cowling dealt with Mr. Hunt for fish.
HARRIET BREWER. I am servant to Thomas Hopper, of Lisson-grove—he deals with Mr. Hunt—between two and three months ago I paid the prisoner 3s. 6d. for Mr. Hunt—he receipted the bill.
COURT. Q. You cannot fix the time exactly? A. No, I am sure it was Whitsuntide—he asked for a pencil—my mistress gave him one, and he wrote his name—here is the bill, it is dated Feb.
MR. HUNT re-examined. I wrote this bill—the dates on it are Feb. 16th, and April 7th.

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

1901.
ELIZABETH CHEVELL was indicted
for stealing 1 sheet, value 2s., 1 shift, 1s.; and 1 handkerchief, 1s.; the goods of
William Holden, her master.
WILLIAM HOLDEN. I am a gardener, and live in Church-street, Chelsea—my wife is a laundress—the prisoner came into my service about twelve

months ago, and staid three or four months—in consequence of something, I discharged her, and then my wife missed something—she is not here—I missed two frilled shirts, and a handkerchief of my wife's—these things produced are our own—we found them at Mr. Grant's, a pawnbroker's—here is our name at full length on them—they are my prop✗rty—I will swear they were in the drawers at the time the prisoner was living with us.
WILLIAM CULLEN. I live in Ebury-street, Pimlic—I received thirty duplicates from Mrs. Arnold, and gave them to the policeman—the prisoner lived in my house—she left just before Whitsuntide.
I am a widow, and live in Spring-garden-palce, Pimlico—the prisoner lodged with me before she went to Mr. Cullen's—she gave me some duplicates to take care of—I gave them to Mr. Cullen.
WILLIAM GOLDING (policeman.) I took the prisoner on another charge—she said she did not care, if there was nothing more than the charge on which I took her.
JOSEPH SMITH (policeman B 40.) I received the duplicated form Mr. Cullen.
SAMUEL HOLLIS. I produce a shirt, a shift, and a handkerchief—I do not know who pledged them—it is upwards of twelve months ago—I gave the person a duplicate—this produced is it.
Prisoner. It is my first offence.

GUILTY. Aged 29.—
Confined Three Months.

1902.
WILLIAM SULLIVAN and
JAMES GRIFFITHS, alias HORAN , were indicted for
stealing 1 pair of boots, value 14s.; the goods of
Thomas Moore; and that they had both been before convicted of felony.

JOHN FRANCIS SHEARGOLD. I am shopman to Thomas Moore, of No.30, Lamb's Conduit-street, boot-maker. On the 11th of Aug., about half-past twelve o'clock in the day, I was in the shop, and saw Sullivan take a pair of boots from inside the door, and hand them to some one outside—I saw Griffiths with them in his hand—Sullivan is lame, he a crutch; I caught hold of him—a person passing laid hold of Griffiths—I saw him drop the boots, I picked them up, and threw them inside the shop—they said they did not touch the boots, and did not know anything about them.

CHARLES WAKE. On the 11th of Aug., in the afternoon, I saw Sullivan in Mr. Sheargold's custody—Griffiths was close to Sullivan, holding these he tried to run away, struck me very violently on the month, and made it bleed.
Griffiths. Q. You tore the buttons from my shirt? A. I took hold of your collar, you rolled yourself into the gutter, and tore your own things—it was your own fault.
EDWARD BAKER (policeman E 124.) I took prisoners into custody, and saw Mr. Wake bleeding from the month—the minute Griffiths saw me he said, "I will go quietly."

Sullivan's Defence. I was looking into the shop, at some slippers; if he had seen me take the boots, he would have taken me immediately, but he touched me on the shoulder, then walked away, and took hold of this lad.
Griffiths' Defence. I was looking into the next shop window; I did not drop the boots; I had nothing to do with them.

JOHN JAMES ALLEN (policeman E 159.) I produce a certificate of Sullivan's former conviction—(read—Convicted Nov., 1846, and confined six months; having been before convicted of felony)—I was present at the trial—he is the person.
ROBERT ROBINSON (policeman N 427.) I produce a certificate of Griffiths former conviction—(read—Convicted Feb., 1847, and confined six months.)

SULLIVAN—
GUILTY. Aged 18.

GRIFFITHS—
GUILTY Aged 18.

1903.
JOHN MACARTHY was indicted
for stealing 1 spoon, value 5s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Ryan; having been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH RYAN. I am a widow, and live in Lambert-street. Last Tuesday week I lost a spoon—it had been just outside the back window-ledge, in the yard, on the Friday form or Saturday before—I afterwards saw it broken—these broken pieces from my spoon, and the one which was out-side my window—a person could get it by coming over a wall, four or five feet high—which is in a public street.

MARY HALE. I am a widow, and live in Lambert-street—the prisoner used once to board with me. On the 12th of Aug., between eleven and twelve o'clock in the morning, he came to me, and said he had found a spoon in the ruins which are nearly opposite my house—I said, "There is no harm in find
ing, my lad; go and find the owner, and the reward of that spoon will be better to you than many spoons, for honesty is the best policy"—I laid the spoon in my window, and am sure this is the same—he came to me about two hours afterwards, and said, "Mrs. Hale, I have found an owner for the spoon"—I said, "I am very glad of it"—I let him have it—it was not broken then, only bruised—in about an hour I saw him passing the door, hailed him in, and said, "What have you done with the spoon?"—he said, "Taken it to the owner"—I said, "What may your reward be?"—he said, "4d."

ELIZABETH LARKIN. I am a widow, and live in Lambert-street. I was washing for Mrs. Ryan on Tuesday and Wednesday week last—she told me on the Tuesday that she had missed a spoon, and on 12th of Aug. I heard a talk about a spoon, and I told Mrs. Ryan about it—she told a policeman, and the spoon was found—I had seen the prisoner on Thursday, about eleven o'clock, lurking near the wall, with his cap off, and raking about the dirt in the ruins—it was after the spoon was lost—some houses had been pulled down there—I have seen rubbish thrown there.

DANIEL LYONS (policeman.) On the 13th of Aug., about one o'clock, I went to a room at the back of No. 16, Lambeth-street—I found the prisoner and his brother there—I woke him up, and asked him if he had anything about him—he said, "No"—I searched him, and found the bowl of silver spoon—I asked where the other part was—he said he had not got it, that he picked this part up on the dust-heap in the ruins—he afterwards produced the other part from his trowser's pocket—I asked him where he got it—he said in the dust-heap in the ruins, that he had sold it to Mrs. Hale for 2d., and had got it back again—he afterwards said he had left it there, and got some bread and cheese on it.

Prisoner's Defence. I was raking for a few bones, and saw the spoon on the dust-heap; I laid the spoon a down; she asked me what I wanted for it; I said, "2d.;" she gave it me; a boy afterwards told me the spoon was silver; I went back and got it, thinking it might do me service.

MARY HALE
re-examined. I lent him the 2d. to buy something to eat, as he said he was hungry—I knew it was silver—I did not tell him so—he afterwards came, gave me 2d., and took the spoon.
CORNELIUS FOAY (policeman.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted May, 1845, and confined two months.)

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1904.
ROBERT GRANDY was indicted
for stealing 2 Spanish dou
bloons, value 6l. 8s.; 6 Mexican dollars, 1l. 4s.; 12 Spanish quarter-dollars, 12s.; and 1 five-franc piece, 4s. 2d.; the monies of
Matteo Storitza.
(MATTEO STORITZA and ADOLFO MORETE being called did not appear.)

CHARLES SLAKER (policeman K 159.) I was called on board the Monte Video, and saw the prisoner—the mate, whose name I do not know, made an accusation against him—it was a foreign name—he said he should not be able to attend, as the ship was going away—he charged the prisoner with stealing Spanish doubloons—he denied it—I took him into custody, searched him, and found nothing on him—he told the sergeant he had stolen the money, and told me so as well—he said he had stolen the money from the ship—he said it was the mate's and mentioned his name—he went with us—as we passed Mr. Snelley's shop there was some money in the window—he said, "There is some money in that window which looks very much like mine"—we went in—I inquired if Mr. Snelley had bought any foreign money of a sailor—he said he had—I asked if he should know the man again—he said he did not know, but that the prisoner was very much like the man—the prisoner did not say anything—we all left the shop, and went to the station—I afterwards took the prisoner to Arbour-square, where I heard him say, "I have stolen the money from the chest of the ship's mate"—he said he had sold it to Mr. Snelley.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Is this the first time you have thought of this? A. No—I do not know why I did not tell it to the Magistrates' clerk—I might have forgotten it—I have seen sergeant Townson since—I have had no conversation with him about what took place at the station-house.

JOHN LAWSON. I am salesman to Mr. Snelley, a pawnbroker, of High-street, Shadwell. On Monday afternoon I purchased twelve Spanish quarter dollars of a sailor—I cannot positively swear to the prisoner.

EDWARD WANDERER TOWNSON (police-sergeant K.) On the 14th of July, in the afternoon, the prisoner was brought to the station—I sent Slaker to bring a witness—while he was gone the prisoner and prosecutor spoke in a foreign language—the prosecutor said, in broken English, "He says he has taken my money"—I said to the prisoner, "Is that the case?"—he said, "Yes, and I changed twelve quarter dollars round the corner; if you will go with me I will show you where the money is"—he took me to 14, George-street, Commercial-road, where he stated his mother lived, went to a chest, and drew out a purse, which he said contained 17s. and two farthings—I opened it, and said, "Are you aware what you have given me?"—he said, "Yes"—I counted it—it was 6l. 17s. in English money—he said it was Storitza's, the mate's, all but the two farthings—on getting outside the house, he said, "Do you think I shall be transported?"—I said, "I cannot say"—when the charge was taken, the mate said his name was "Matteo Storitza"—he wrote it in my presence, in the charge-room.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he come to you before he went to sea? A. Yes—he said he should make me responsible for the money, and if he came back he should charge the prisoner again—he would have stopped, but would have lost his situation.

FRANCIS PIMOTELLI. I am a licensed victualler, at Wellclose-square—I have known the prisoner since he was a boy—Storitza is a countryman of mine—on the Sunday before this, I saw them on board the ship together, and

had a conversation with them—the prisoner had two Spanish dollars, and two quarter dollars, in a little purse—he had two quarter dollars a month—he asked me how much they were worth in London—I saw that he had money—I afterwards saw him with a Spanish dollar, some Mexican dollars, and two quarter gold doubloons—that was before he went to Mr. Snelley's to change them—I am an Italian—I did not hear any conversation between the prisoner and Storritza about the money—I have known the prisoner from his infancy—he bears a very good character for honesty—Storritza engaged him for the ship at my house.
NEW COURT. Monday, August 23rd, 1847.
PRESENT—Mr. Alderman FARNCOMB; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.

div1.p:
1905.
WILLIAM WELSH
was indicated for stealing 1 bed-tick, value 2s. and 2 sheets, 1s. 6d.; the property of
John Labouchere and others, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 51.—
Confined Sir Months.

1906.
DAVID EDWARDS
was indicated for embezzling 7l. 9s. 10d., the monies of
Septimus Scott, and others, his masters, to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 39.—
Confined Nine Months.

1907.
HENRY EVANS
was indicated for embezzling 2s., the monies of
James Newell, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY , Aged 15.—
Confined Four Months. (There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1908.
WILLIAM ALDRIDGE was indicted
for embezzling 20s., the money of
Frederick Putnam, his master; having been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Confined Nine Months.

1909.
CHARLES EVANS was indicted
for stealing 15 shirts, value 1l. 2s. 6d.; 2 shifts, 2s. 1 table-cloth, 3s.; 2 pairs of trowsers, 3s.; 2 handkerchiefs, 2s. 1 waistcoat, 1s. 6d.; 2 towels, 1s.; 1 apron, 6d. 1 pillow-case, 6d. and 1 petticoat, 1s.; the property of
John Maynard, having been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1910.
SARAH TAYLOR was indicted
for staling 1lb. of soap, value 6d.; 1lb. of sugar, 6d.; and 2oz. of tea, 6d.; the property of
Francis Virgo Sanderson, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Ten Days, it being stated that a person would take her into his employment.

1911.
GEORGE TINKIN was indicted
for embezzlement.
CHARLES WHEATLEY. I knew the prisoner in the service of Mr. Andrew Nicol, a baker—in May, 1846, the prisoner called on me for some money for Mr. Nicol—I paid him 10s. out of a larger sum.
Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Did you take a receipt for it? A. Yes.
SARAH SALMON. I am the wife of David Salmon—I knew the prisoner by coming as Mr. Nicol's servant—I paid him 1l. 0s. 6d. in May last year on account of Mr. Nicol.

ANDREW NICOL. The prisoner was in my service in May, 1846—he re
ceived money for me, and accounted for it—he never accounted in any way for, or paid me these sums—he ought to have paid them on the Sunday fol
lowing.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you transact business on Sunday morning? A. Yes, if we have not time on Saturday night—he had authority to collect money for me—he was not in the habit of paying himself his wages and handing me the balance—he has done so when I told him—he was given in custody on the 30th of last month—he had asked me on the Saturday before he received this money, to book up his account, but I was very busy, and said he had better go home—his wages were 1l. 0s. 6d. a week.

COURT Q. Did you pay his wages? A. Yes—there was no money due to him on the day he received these sums—they were paid on Monday, and he left me on the Saturday following—he used to account to Mrs. Nicol sometimes—she is not here.
MR. O'BRIEN. Q. How is it you did not give him in charge since June last year? A. I could not find him—he left me without a man.

GUILTY. Aged 35.—
Confined Two Months.

1912.
ELIZABETH PARTRIDGE was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 17s.; and 1 waistcoat, 3s.; the property of
John Adams.
JOHN ADAMS. I lodge in New-court, Marylebone—on the 12th of July I gave the prisoner my coat and waistcoat to take care of—this is my coat.
CHARLES PAIN. I am a pawnbroker—I produce this coat, it was pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I pawned it, but not with intent to steal it.

GUILTY. Aged 35.—
Confined Nine Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1913.
JOSEPH CAIN was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 1l.; the goods of
Richard Thomas Mickleburgh, from his person.

RICHARD THOMAS MICKLEBURGH. I am a schoolmaster, and live in Devonshire. On the 17th of Aug., between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was coming from the Strand with my brother, and at the gate I found a great crowd attracted by a fire; and in following my brother, who had passed through, I felt some one snatch my watch from my waistcoat pocket—the hand was caught in my guard—I immediately seized the guard and caught the person by the collar—it was the prisoner—I took the guard off his arm, and before I liberated him I gave him to the policeman—my watch was gone out.
of my pocket in a moment—I went with the prisoner to the station and gave him in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. There was a great crowd? A. Yes—my brother had forced his way through the gate—I could not get through—I am sure I kept the person whose hand I found in my guard—his hand was entangled in the guard—a few minutes before I approached the gate my brother had cautioned me, and I felt my watch safe—the snatch at my pocket was made by the same person whose hand was in my guard—I felt a dash at my pocket—I was not in the crowd above half a minute—I seized both the hand and the collar of the prisoner—I heard him say I was never more mistaken, and that he was not the person—I called the policeman—he came through the gate to me—I then went to Bow-street station-house—I was surrounded on all sides—there was a greater crowd before me than there was behind me—my watch was on a swivel—the swivel was not broken—the watch must have been broken off it.

GUILTY.*.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1914.
WILLIAM BROWN CHATWIN was indicted
for bigamy.

HARRIET ANDERSON. I live in Darling-street, Bethnal-green. I was married to the prisoner at Greenwich church about fifteen months ago—the ceremony was performed in the vestry-room—I had lived with him three or four months before, and have lived with him ever since.
JOSEPH LUCAS. I live in Suffolk-street, Bethnal-green. I was at Hackney church when the prisoner was married to my sister Rebecca—he lived with her after the marriage—I saw her about nine days ago.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE Q. Was she married in her right name? A. I do not know—I cannot answer whether Rebecca Lucas was her right name—I know her mother was not my mother, as I am told—I do not know that she was treated as an illegitimate child—she went by the name of Rebecca Lucas—I never heard her called anything else.

JAMES WEST (policeman K 113.) I produce a certificate of the marriage of William Brown Chatwin, bachelor, and Rebecca Lucas, spinster, at Hack
ney church, in the presence of Joseph Lucas and Mary Ann Lucas—I have compared this with the register—it is correct.

JOHN RIVERS FOUNTAIN. I am parish clerk at Greenwich—I produce a certificate of marriage from the parish Church of St. Alphage—I am not clerk of that Church—persons are never married in the vestry in that Church that I know of—William Brown Chatwin and Harriet Anderson were married at St. Alphage on the 16th of June, 1846.

GUILTY. Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1915.
ALFRED YARNOLD was indicted
for stealing 1 half-crown, the monies of
William John Martin, his master.

THOMAS MUNN. I live at 375, Oxford-street. In consequence of some circumstance I marked four half-crowns, and gave them to Mr. Howard to go to a shop, No. 147, Edgware-road, to purchase goods—this is one of the half-crowns I gave him—the prisoner was then in the service of Mr. William John Martin, for whom I was then managing.
Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. How long had you been in Mr. Martin's service? A. About four months—I think the prisoner had been about nine months in his service—I have had no quarrel with him—the

mark on this half-crown is under the date, 1816—it was about a quarter-past five o'clock when this money was sent in—there are two other persons engaged in that shop beside the prisoner—they have the selling of goods and the taking of money—the prisoner slept in a room over the shop—the two other young men slept in the same room, in separate beds.
THOMAS HOWARD. I live in Crown-street, Westminster. Mr. Munn gave me some money—I went to the shop and paid the prisoner four half-crowns—this is one of the half-crowns I paid him.

Cross-examined. Q. What time was this? A. A quarter-past five o'clock—I bought 3lbs. of tea—I paid the prisoner four half-crowns and three shil
lings—they were all marked—I saw no one in the shop but the prisoner, who served me with the goods.

HENRY SMITH (policeman A 28.) I went to the house, No 147, Edg
ware-road—I saw the prisoner, and told him I was a police-officer, and was going to take him into custody for stealing a half-crown from the till—he said, "Search me and welcome, I have not got it"—I searched him, but did not find it—I went up stairs, and asked which was his box—he told me—I did not find the half-crown there—I went down and asked the woman there, in the prisoner's presence, if he had been up stairs—he said he had not—the woman said he had—he then said he had been to wash his hands—I went up again, and then found this half-crown in his box—he said, "It is my first time, forgive me."

Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he had never been changed with any thing before? A. No—when I went up the first time and searched his box I found nothing—that was about half-past five o'clock—the prisoner went up with me, I searched the box in his presence—I took him down again to the bottom of the stairs—I then went up again and found this half-crown amongst some rubbish in a paper bag—the box was unlocked—there were two other beds in that room, and there were other boxes—I took all the things out of the prisoner's box the first time, but I did not examine the little bag so closely as I did the second time—there was another young man, who came out from his tea into the shop.
WILLIAM CLEW (police-inspector.) This is Mr. Long's handwriting to this deposition—(read)—the prisoner says, "It is the first time I ever attempted such a thing; I have a wife dependent on me."
Cross-examined. Q. Were you present when the prisoner was examined? A. No, I know nothing about the case.

GUILTY. Aged 30.—
Confined One Year.

1916.
JOHN POLISHER and
JOHN PHILLIPS were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; the goods of
John Bond Haydon, form his person; Phillips having been before convicted of felony.

JOSEPH DALTON (City policeman 366.) On the 6th of Aug. I was in Cheapside in plain clothes—I saw the prisoners, and, knowing them, I followed them to Holborn-hill—they stopped near Chancery-lane, where there was a crowd—I saw the prosecutor—the prisoners went near him, and I saw Polisher put his hand into his pocket, and take out this handkerchief—the prisoners then walked away—I told the prosecutor his pocket was picked—I took the prisoners to the station, and took this handkerchief out of Polisher's pocket.

COURT. Q. How long had you seen the prisoners together? A. I fol
lowed them from Cheapside to Holborn-hill—they had not tried any other pockets—Phillips stood as close to Polisher as he could, while Polisher took the handkerchief, to hide anyone from seeing him.

JOHN BOND HAYDON. I am a solicitor, and live in Field-court, Gray's-inn. On the 6th of Aug. I was at a shop-window near Chancery-lane—I had a handkerchief in my pocket shortly before, and I lost it—this is it.

Philips's Defence. I was coming through Cheapside when Polisher spoke to me; we were going on together, and were overtaken by the officer, who charged us with this; I know nothing about it; I never saw the handker
chief till I was taken.

JOSEPH DALTON
re-examined. I produce a certificate of Phillips's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted on the 14th of Dec., 1846, by the name of William Gray, and confined six months)—he is the person.

POLISHER—
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

PHILLIPS—
GUILTY Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1917.
JOHN HENRY MANN was indicted
for stealing 1 box, value 1d.; and 2 watch movements, 6s.; the goods of
George John Oram, and another, his masters.

GEORGE JOHN ORAM. I am in partnership with my father, George Samuel Oram, in Whiskin-street—the prisoner was our apprentice. I went out on the evening of the 27th of July, and left him at work—I came home about eleven o'clock, and he was gone—I did not miss anything then, but on the following day the policeman came, and missed two watch movements—these produced are what I lost.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. I believe he has behaved very well before? A. I never found him dishonest before—he was rather apt to play a few tricks, and to indulge in strange peculiarities and fancies—he was rather self-willed and headstrong—I have had some trouble with him—he has always been with me at the business, and worked regular hours.

EDWARD KELL (police-sergeant S 84.) About one o'clock in the morning on the 28th of July, I met the prisoner and another boy in Holloway—I stopped them, and asked them where they were going—the prisoner said, "To Barnet, and from there to Liverpool"—he said he was in no business, he was going to get what he could—I searched him, and found these movements on him—I asked whose they were—he said they were his own, that he bought them in Petticoat-lane for three shillings, and he was going to dispose of them to help him on the road.

Cross-examined. Q. He would tell you nothing about himself? A. He would not—he was taken to the police-court, and remanded—we found from the police book where his master resided—the other boy was dis
charged.

MRS. SALISBURY. I am the prisoner's sister—I saw several articles which looked like these, in his possession before this—he showed them to me—he wanted to make a watch for himself—he is a very honest boy, but very tricksy.

1918.
SAMUEL CHARLES PRINCE was indicted
for stealing 1 half-eagle, value 28s.; the monies of
Eric Orr; in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.

ERIC ORR. I am second mate of the James Edwards, which is in the St. Katharine's Docks; the prisoner was steward. On the 26th of July I lost a half-eagle, which is worth about 1l. 8s.—the prisoner had wanted to borrow money of me the day before, and I told him I had not got any—he had no business in my berth that I know of—I missed this piece of money—I took the prisoner to my room and spoke to him—he stated at first that he had not taken it—at last he said he had taken the half-eagle piece, and told me to say nothing about it, that he might not have discharge—I told him there was no necessity for it, he had been bad enough without—he had put the money in a house, and spent a cent of it.

Prisoner. I never took it all; I went to speak to the mate, and this witness called me into the state-room, and had a rope's-end; he said I had taken the piece; I said I had not, but sooner than have a piece of work I would pay more than the value of it.

ROBERT GIFFORD (policeman.) I took the prisoner—he said he knew nothing about it; but sooner than have any piece of work he would pay five times the amount—the next morning he asked if he should plead guilty—I told him I should give him no advice—he then said, "I took the money, but it was through drink and the persuasion of another party."

ANN WILSON. I live at No.4, Neptune-court. On Sunday night the prisoner came to sleep in that house, and he left his coat for the price of the room, he had no money—on Monday night, the 26th, he came again with a gold piece.
Prisoner. I had twenty dollars which the captain paid me; it was my own money.

COURT to ERIC ORR. Q. Did he received twenty dollars? A. The cap
tain would not give him a farthing—I swear he never had a farthing—his pay was twenty dollars a month; but he acted in such a way that he was not worth a farthing—he wasted more victuals, and spoiled more than he was worth.

Prisoner. This witness told me the captain was a very bad captain, and he said he would take his gold watch and throw it overboard; I am as innocent as you are; I did not take it. I assure; I had my trunk full of clothes, and 5l. owing to me; the Magistrate said I might have them, but the ship was gone to sea and I could not get them.

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

1919.
GEORGE WAKEFIELD was indicted for
staling 3 bushels of beans, value 16s.; and 4 sacks 4s.; the goods of
Walter Powell, his master: and
CHARLES GOBBY
for feloniously receiving the same, well-knowing them to have been stolen.

HENRY LOADES. I am in the employ of Mr. Walter Powell—I know the prisoner Wakefield—he was in Mr. Powell's employ. On the 1st of July he was ordered to take three sacks of oats and some straw to Mr. Fordham—I helped him load—he told me to take a sack of oats into Gobby's—I took it—I hallooed out, no one answered, and I left it on the stairs—I saw Wake-field again that night—he owed me a shilling, and I asked him if he could pay me, and he gave me 3s.—the sack of oats came from my master's loft, where the other sacks came from.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What did you get the 3s. for? A. I do not know, unless he meant to lend it me—we have been in the habit of lending and borrowing—I am quite innocent—I did not know whether I was doing right or wrong—when I got the extra 2s., I did not ask what it was for—people do not often give me 2s. for nothing—I did not know whether he meant to lend it me—we do lend and borrow, without asking each other for it—I left the sack with a little girl, and said, "Here is a sack of oats for Mr. Gobby"—I have known Gobby to be a customer of my master's—I have not lent him any sacks—I do not know whether he has had sacks of my master—when he has bought things, he has brought his own sack—I never knew sacks of my master's to go there.

MARY OAKFORD. I live in Hatton-garden. On the 1st of July, between three and four o'clock, I saw a sack taken to Gobby's premises by Wakefield—it appeared to be full—I could not see what was in it—it was a new sack, similar to this one, and marked in red letters, "W. Powell."

WALTER POWELL. I am a corn-dealer, and live in Leather-lane—Gobby has bought things at my place—the last oats he bought of me, was on the 10th of March—in consequence of information I went to his house with a constable—when he came home, I asked him if he had any empty sacks of mine—he denied it strongly—I said, "I think you have"—I went into his stable, and he chucked a sack off a rail—I said that was not mine—he then chucked down two sacks, which were mine—he said he did not know how he came by them, he used them for chaff—I looked into one, and I said, "This does not look like chaff; here are oats in this"—I then asked if he had any more sacks—he said, "No, only those two empty sacks"—I said I was quite certain he had got sacks up stairs—he said he had no place up stairs, and he was quite sure he had no sacks at all up stairs—I then asked him if he would allow me and the officer to go up—he said it was no use going, there were no sacks there—we went up, and there was a sack in the pas
sage—it could not be seen from the bottom—it contained about a bushel and a half oats—I looked at them, and said, "These are some of my oats"—Gobby said, "Yes, I had them of George"—we asked him to let us go up higher—he said he had nothing more—we went up, and found a sack with a bushel and a half of beans—he said, "I did not have them of your man; I took your sack to fetch them in"—I opened the sack, and I said, "These are my beans"—he said, "Yes, I had them of George," or "the man"—I said, "What do you mean by allowing me to be robbed?"—he said he hoped I would forgive him, that he had seven or nine children, and he said, "George told me he worked at a vessel, and he had got these overplus"—he said he gave the man a sovereign for the oats and beans, through his spending a shilling, and he borrowed part of the money at the public-house—I gave 2l. 0s. 6d. a quarter for the beans, on the 9th of Jan., but as they were damaged, I should have taken perhaps 38s. for them—they heated in the sacks, and were damaged a little.

Cross-examined. Q. In fact they were damaged? A. They were good beans when I bought them—they had heated, and there were a few sacks a little damaged—those I found at Gobby's were so damaged, that I could not send them to customers as sweet beans—there were plenty of them good—they were worth 4s. a bushel—I should be sure to get that for them if I had them at home—I might not have said at the Police-office that he begged I would forgive him—I will not swear that I said anything about his wife and children.

JOHN GUNN (policeman G 224.) I went with the prosecutor to Gobby's—he came home with his van—the prosecutor asked him if he had any of his sacks on his premises—he hesitated, and said he did not know, or something to that effect—the gates of the stable were wide open, and we walked in—Gobby took two sacks off he place, and said, "I believe I have a sack or two of yours here"—the first he took, Mr. Powell said, "This is not mine"—he took down two more, and Mr. Powell said, "These are mine; how did you come by them?"—he said, "I do not know, they have been here some time"—Mr. Powell said, "Have you got any up stairs?"—he said, "Up stairs I have got no place for sacks"—Mr. Powell said, "I am informed you have; will you allow, me to look?"—he said, "I have no place up stairs"—I then said, "I am a constable; if you have no sacks, you can have no objection to our going up"—he said, "I have only got my room up stairs," and he looked round the stable, and said, "Here is all the place I have got for food for my horse"—at last he said, "We will all go up stairs"—there is a door from the stable to the bottom of the stair-case, and as soon as that was opened, on the first step, I tumbled against a sack—I showed it to Mr. Powell—he said, "This is one of my sacks; will you allow me to look at the corn?"—Gobby said, "Yes"—Mr. Powell put his hand in, and said, "This is very much like my corn"—Gobby said, "I know it is, I bought it of your George"—we went up stairs, and in the bedroom found two sacks—one con
tained whole beans, and one split beans—Mr. Powell put his hand in the latter, and said, "These are my beans"—Gobby said, "Yes, I know they are; I bought them of your George the same time that 1 bought the oats"—Mr. Powell said, "How could you rob me in that manner?"—he said, "George told me there was an over plus of the vessel, and I paid him a sovereign, and he spent a shilling"—he talked about his looking over it, but I will not sat what—my attention was directed to the beans.
(Gobby received a good character.)

WAKEFIELD—
GUILTY. Aged 25.

GOBBY—
GUILTY.
(There was another indictment against the prisoners.)

1920.
THOMAS JOHNSON was indicted for
stealing 50 veneers, value 8s.; the goods of
Charles Watson, his master; and
GEORGE JOHNSON and
MARY ANN JOHNSON
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen: to which

THOMAS JOHNSON pleaded
GUILTY.

MARY ANN WATSON. I am the wife of Charles Watson, of Arthur-street, St. Luke's—he makes boxes and writing-desks, and uses veneers—on the morning of the 2nd of July I came down stairs, about seven o'clock in the morning—I found the parlour-door was pushed against me—on going in, I found Thomas Johnson behind the door, and another man ran to the back-room—I found an apron laid on the floor, full of veneers, and Thomas Johnson's pockets were full of veneers—the strange man pushed me on one side, and ran away—I called my husband, and he came down—I have not seen George Johnson or Mary Ann Johnson there.

CHARLES WATSON. I came down on the morning of the 2nd of July—I found 200 or 300 veneers—those which were in the apron were worth about 35s.—I went an officer to the house where Mary Ann Johnson lives, about ten minutes before eight o'clock, about an hour after my wife made

the discovery—I found her kneeling on the floor, cramming veneers into the fire as fast as she could—I observed the veneers—they were mine—I should think there were fifty or sixty pieces—they were mahogany, and are used for making desks—I am satisfied they were mine—she said a man had hallooed up stairs, and told her to put them in the fire as soon as possible—I have caught George Johnson on my premises.

GEORGE JOHNSON—
NOT GUILTY.

MARY ANN JOHNSON—
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

1921.
THOMAS JOHNSON was again indicted for
stealing 150 pieces of veneer, value 10s.; the goods
Charles Watson, his master; and
HENRY HART
for feloniously receiving the same: to which

THOMAS JOHNSON pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

CHARLES WATSON. On the morning of the 2nd of July I found a quantity of veneer being removed—I went in the course of that morning to Mr. Melton, mentioned the circumstance to him, and he showed me 200 or 300 veneers, which I am quite positive were mine—they were very bad ones, and were worth about 12s.—I received information, and went to Hart's lodging—I found him in bed—I asked him where those veneers were which he had offered Mr. Melton for sale—he said he had shown them to a man named Jennings—we went to Jennings', and found about 500 veneers—they were all mine—I went to Coker's, and found, I should think, 200 or 300, which were worth about 30s.—those at Jennings' were worth 7l. or 8l.—I found some locks and hinges of mine at Mr. Bayley's worth 14s. or 15s.—Hart is a cabinet-maker, he has worked for me.

THOMAS MELTON. I am a cabinet-maker—I produced some veneers to Mr. Watson—I bought them of Hart for 6s.—there were from 200 to 300—I told him they were of no use to me—he had offered me a lot of veneers previous to that, but I did not buy them, I did not see them—he said he had a lot to sell, if I wanted to buy them—I bought this lot of him—I asked him if they were come honestly by—he told me he bought them, and he was going to work some himself—I said, "They are of no use to me; if I buy them, I must take them to Mr. Watson."

JAMES COKER (a prisoner.) I remember the prosecutor coming to my house with the policeman—I produced some veneers to him—I had bought about 200 of them of Hart—he took wood in exchange for them—he said they were his own, and it was all right—I can hardly tell what day he sold them to me—it was about five weeks before Mr. Melton called on me—I had two dealings with Hart, the second time I bought about sixty of him.

EDWARD JENNINGS (a prisoner.) I remember the prosecutor finding some veneers at my house—I bought them of Hart, about a fortnight before the prosecutor came—I bought them in two separate lots, for about 25s., alto
gether—I put them under the boards at my house—I had no other place to keep them from being spoiled.
Hart. I bought all these things of one man, who is not taken into custody.

THOMAS DAVIS. I bought five dozen locks of Hart, on the Saturday night, as Epsom races were on the Monday; I sold them to Mr. Bayley; I took Mr. Watson to Mr. Bayley, and he recognized the property in my presence.

CHARLES WATSON
re-examined. I saw the property at Mr. Bayley's, that and all the other property was mine.

HART—
GUILTY. Aged 28.—
Confined One Year.

1922.
WILLIAM BASTERFIELD and
WILLIAM DAVEY were in
dicted for
stealing 4 bushels of mixed oats and chaff, value 7s.; and 1 sack, 6d.; the goods of
Samuel Pocock, and another, the master of Basterfield; to which

BASTERFIELD pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 49.—
Confined Six Months.

EDWARD HENRY CHAMBERS. I am horse-keeper to Messrs. Samuel and Lewis Pocock, of Phoenix-wharf, White Friars. Basterfield was their carman—he went out with a team on the 20th of July—I delivered him two sacks, one contained about four bushels of horse-feed, consisting of clover, chaff; and oats, which he was to give to his horses—the property produced is my masters', and is worth 6s. or 7s.

CHARLES RANDELL (policeman N 172.) I saw Basterfield come out of the field, and I watched him to Davey's shop—Davey came out and spoke to him, he then went on, and Davey ran after him, and overtook him—Basterfield then lifted a sack out of the cart—Davey took it on his back, and went to
wards his own stable with it—I stopped him.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Davey went away with it? A. Yes, he hurried away—I told the clerk twice that he hurried away—I do not know whether is is written down that he walked—he went in the direction of his own stable—I asked him where he got it—he said he bought it of a man—I asked him which man—he pointed to Basterfield, and my brother con
stable took him into custody.
COURT. Q. What shop does Davey keep? A. A greengrocer's—the names, "Samuel Pocock and Lewis Pocock, Caledonian-fields," were on the cart.

DAVEY—
NOT GUILTY.

1923.
JANE CLINE was indicted
for stealing 2 sheets, value 5s.; 2 pet
tocoats, 3s.; 2 handkerchiefs, 3s.; 2 bed-gowns, 3s.; and 1 sheet, 5s.; the goods of
Henry Willaim Byrn, her master; and that she had been before con
victed of felony
WILLIAM AYRES. I am a pawnbroker. I produce a sheet pawned by a woman—the duplicates which are produced by the officer correspond with the property produced, and with the duplicates which I have.
WILLIAM THOMAS (policeman T 60.) I went to the prisoner's house—I found there a towel, a handkerchief, several pieces of lace, and twenty-six duplicates, some of which Mr. Ayres has identifies.
MARY BYRN. I am the wife of Henry William Byrn, and am a laundress. The prisoner washed for me—I lost all this property—some of it is mine, and some is my employers'.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you able to identify these articles? A. Yes, many of them—the names have been taken out of some—the prisoner is married, and has six children—I have heard that her husband does not allow her much, and I felt for her.

JOHN JONES (police-sergeant T 31.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction—(read—Convicted 5th of April, 1841, and confined four months.)—she is the person.

GUILTY.* Aged 32.—
Confined One Year.

1924.
THOMAS TINDALL was indicted
for embezzlement.
CHARLES HEDGE. I am a coal-merchant, at Eaton-wharf, Pimlico. The

prisoner was my servant—it was his duty to receive money—the money brought to the wharf it was his duty to pay to me each night—if he received 2l. 5s. 6d., and 1l. 2s. on the 27th of July, he has not paid it to me—he ought to have paid them both.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. He was in the habit of receiving large sums? A. No, not large sums—5l. or 6d. a day—he may have in
tended to pay me these sums, but I do not know where the money was to come from—he gave me no account of them.
ANN CHIGNELL. I had coals of the prosecutor—on the 27th of July I paid the carman (Gilder) 1l. 2s.—this is the receipt.
JOHN GILDER. I am the carman—I received the money from Mrs. Chignell; I gave it to the prisoner, who is the clerk.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you recollect giving him that 1l. 2s.? A. Yes—I have received a little money from time to time—I received this money for Mr. Coomb—these were not Mr. Hedges' coals at all.
WILLIAM BURTON. I paid 2l. 5s. 6d. about the 24th of July to the prisoner for Mr. Hedge.

MR. ROBINSON to MR. HEDGE. Q. Have you any partner? A. No—Mr. Coomb does his business at the wharf, and sends out coals—it was the duty of the prisoner to receive this money and hand it to me—I am answer
able for it.

COURT. Q. You directed the prisoner, your servant, to receive it? A. Yes—it was his duty to pay the money received of Mrs. Chignell to Mr. Coomb—the 2l. 5s. 6d. paid by Mr. Burton to the prisoner was my money.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p: (There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1925.
THOMAS KIRKMAN and
JOHNWALKER were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d.; 3 half-crowns; and 2s.; the pro
perty of
Arthur Burnell, from his person.

ARTHUR BURNELL. I live in James'-terrace, Camden-town—on the evening of the 23rd of July, I was with some friends in the Commercial-road—I got intoxicated—I then came to Whitechapel-raod—I lost a silk handkerchief, and about 14s. in money—some was in pocket behind, and some in my trowsers pocket—this is my handkerchief, when I got sober I identified it.

THOMAS KELLY (policeman 119 H.) I was in plain clothes in White-chapel-road that night, and saw the prisoners with Burnell—they brought him to the Brass Founder's Arms—he would not go in there, and they took him to Fieldgate-street, and then on to the Commercial-road—they got him into a public-house—he was there perhaps twenty minutes—they went from there to a cook's shop—I saw Burnell use his handkerchief before he went into the cook's shop—I staid till they came out—they went to another public-house, and were still dragging him along—they then separated—I took Walker on suspicion of robbing Burnell—on our way across the road, Walker tried to drop this handkerchief, but we caught it—Kirkman was standing a little further on.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Kirkman had left the prose
cutor? A. Yes—Walker used a great deal of exertion to get the prosecutor
into the public-house—I have inquired about Kirkman, and find he is a respectable hard-working man.
THOMAS GIFFORD (policeman, H 89.) I saw Walker attempt to drop the handkerchief—I took Kirkman.

KIRKMAN—
NOT GUILTY.

WALKER—
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1926.
SAMUEL MAGINN and
WILLIAM SCALES were indicted for
stealing 1 fire lump, value 2s. 3d.; and 1 brick, 2s. 3d.; the goods of
John Cherry, the master of Scales, Scales having been before convicted of felony.

JOHN CHERRY. I am a carman, and live in Middle-row, Goswell-street—Scales was in my service—I have been employed by Messrs. Moreland to cart goods for them—I employed Scales on the 30th of July to cart some Welsh lumps and bricks for them.

JOHN CONNELL. On the 30th of July I saw a cart driven by Scales, stop in Ironmonger-row, Maginn took a lump out of the hinder part of the cart and took it into his own house—Scales was standing close by the cart.
Maginn. The lump was not found in my house—I was told to carry it into the house.
JOSEPH MORELAND. I have seen the lumps—I had them weighed and measured—they exactly correspond with I had, and which I employed Cherry to carry—they are mine.

JOHN CHERRY
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Were these lumps yours? A. No, they were Mr. Moreland's—they were never given to me—I never saw them.
CHARLES WOOLNER. (policeman 153 G.) I produce these six lumps which I found in Maginn's kitchen.

ANN JOHNSON. I occupy the bottom part of the house, No. 23, Iron
monger-row—these lumps were in the yard there, and they were taken down into the kitchen for Maginn.
(Peter Stevens, a house-agent, gave Maginn a good character.)
JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant 20 G.) I produce a certificate of Scales' former conviction—(read—Convicted Dec., 1844, and confined fourteen days solitary)—he is the person.

MAGINN—
GUILTY.

SCALES—
GUILTY. Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1927.
SAMUEL MAGINN was again indicted with
WILLIAM PET
TITT
for stealing 1 fire lump, value 2s. 3d.; and 1 brick, 2s. 3d.; the goods of
John Cherry, the master of Pettitt.

JAMES LARGE. At a quarter past two o'clock, in the afternoon, on the 2nd of Aug., I saw Maginn take a lump out of the tail of the cart, into his own house—Pettit was the carman—he turned his back towards the cart while Maginn took it out—I followed the cart to Mr. Moreland's house—I gave information, and had the prisoner taken—I went with the officer to Maginn's house, and found six lumps there—he took the lump at the corner of Wenlock-street, about forty yards from his house.
JOHN CHERRY. I employed Pettit to drive a cart on the 2nd of Aug.
JOSEPH MORELAND. I have examined these lumps—I am positive they are mine—the prisoners had to carry a great quantity of them for me.
Maginn. I was asked by Mrs. Johnson to carry them out of the yard.
ANN JOHNSON. They were put into my yard—I had to clean the yard, and I said, "Move them down in the kitchen"—they were not brought in for me.
Pettitt's Defence. Maginn said a man wished to look at this lump, and if it did not suit, I was to have it when I came back; I let him have it.

MAGINN—
GUILTY. † Aged 28.

PETTITT—
GUILTY. † Aged 48.—

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Alderman GIBBS, Mr. RECORDER, Mr. Alderman WOOD, and Mr. Alderman SIDNEY.

div1.p:
1928.
DANIEL O' DONNELL,
JEREMIAH CONDON , and
JOHN HOGAN , were indicted for
stealing 1 gelding, price 5l., the property of
Henry Lovett.

THOMAS LAWS (policeman C 112.) On Tuesday, the 3rd of Aug., I saw the prisoners in Marylebone-street, with a horse in their possession—O' Don
nell and Condon were leading it by these two comforters—one was tied round the nose and head, and the other attached as a rein—Hogan was close by, in company with them—I asked them where they had got the horse—O'Don
nell said, "We found it"—I said it was strange to find an old horse like that, and asked where they found it—Condon said, "In the Bayswater-road"—I asked him where he was going to take it to—he said, "To the station-house"—I asked what station-house—he said, "Any one"—I said, "Well, here is a station-house very near here, I will take the horse and you there," which I did.

O' Donnell. We met it in the Bayswater-road—we were asking the people for the station-house when he came up. Witness. They were speaking to some persons—I believe these comforters to be their own—they must have passed the Marylebone station, which they know as well as I do.

HENRY LOVETT. I live in Wood field-road, Harrow-road. I had a grey gelding in a field in the Harrow-road—I saw it safe about half-past one o'clock in the afternoon of the 3rd of Aug.; and about two, when I went to fetch it, it was gone—it was the same horse that was stopped by the officer—the field is about three miles from Marylebone-street—there was no mound on one side of the field—they are building there—the horse could have got out of the field, but he would not do so—there is very good pasture there—it had been there two months—the gate opens into the Harrow-road—when I left the horse about half-past one o'clock, it was in the centre of the field—there was another horse with it—that remained there—it was rather a better one than mine, and they could not catch it—if it had strayed from the field it could not very well have got into the Bayswater-road, because they were laying down pipes there, and it could not have got by the men and the fires—I had not seen the prisoners about my premises.
JOHN MILLIGAN. I live with my father, a sculptor, No. 1, Edgware-road,

near the prosecutor's. I met the three prisoner together, about a quarter past two o'clock, coming down the Harrow-road, with the horse, not more than forty yards from the field—Condon was riding it—I knew the horse, as my father has borrowed it—Condon had a red comforter for a bridle, and a black handkerchief for the reins—it was a very quiet horse.

O'Donnell. That boy was fetched up the first time that we were remanded, but he did not say what he does now; he said he could not swear to us; the Magistrate would not take his evidence, and they fetched up a ginger-beer man, who said it was two young men that entered the field, and he did not see them take the horse out. Witness. The Magistrate did not refuse to take my evidence.

WILLIAM YOUNG
re-examined. The prisoners were remanded, as the pro
secutor said that two lobouring men in the field had told him that three hod-boys had taken the horse—we could not find those men, but a ginger-beer man said he saw two boys go into the field and take the horse out—he could not swear to the prisoners; and then the Magistrate asked for the boy—he was not there that day, and I subpoena'd him.
Hogan. Q. Did not we follow you to the station-house? A. You did.
O' Donnell's Defence. We found the horse running down the Bayswater-road; we stopped it, and put our comforters round him, intending to take it to the station-house or the Green-yard.

Condon's Defence. We were out looking for work, and saw the horse in the road; some gentleman asked us to stop it; we ran after it, and caught it, and tied the comforters round its neck; we went along with it, asking of every cab man we met if he knew of a Green-yard.

Hogan's Defence. We stopped the horse in the road, took off our com
forters, and tied them round his neck.

JANE HOGAN. I am the prisoner's sister. He was at work on the Mon
day before this, and on the Tuesday he went out, and was not gone ten minutes before I heard he was taken—I saw the other two boys not a quarter of an hour before, and am sure they had not time to go very far.

1929.
MICHAEL JOHNSON was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Richard Brannan, and stabbing, cutting, and wounding him on his left arm, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

RICHARD BRANNAN. I am a porter, and live in Red Lion-street, White-chapel. On the 7th of Aug., about a quarter before twelve o'clock, I was in Grace's-alley, Wellclose-square, and saw the prisoner there striking a young women—I said, "Why not leave the women alone?"—he then left her, and seized me by the neck-handkerchief, twisted it round, and nearly choked me—a constable came up, and sent him one way, and me another—when I had got about 150 yards from the spot, he came running back—he ran past me about a yard or two, then turned suddenly round, and aimed a blow at me, which I thought was with his fist—he then stepped little way back; and as he rose his hand a second time, I caught the reflection of the blade of a knife, or some sharp instrument—it was under a gas-lamp—I then hit him, and knocked him down—he aimed a second blow, which cut me slightly on the neck—I found my arm cut about an inch, or rather better—I was taken to the hospital, and am there still.
Prisoner. I had no knife on me, nor was any found—there were sailors and others round—he had me on the ground, and two men were on me—they took my handkerchief and cap from me, and he collared me.
Witness. I did not—no one struck me but him—the policeman came up just at the time he made the second blow.

SILVANUS GILL (policeman H 155.) A little before twelve o'clock on Saturday night, the seventh of Aug., I saw the prisoner and prosecutor scuffling together in Grace's-alley—they had hold of each other by the collar—the prisoner wanted me to take charge of the prosecutor for striking him—I separated them and sent one one way and one the other—I then went on my beat—I was fetched back by a female, and saw the prosecutor bleeding very much from the arm, stating that he was stabbed—a house was pointed out to me where the prisoner had gone—I gained admittance, got a candle, searched the house, and found him in a water-closet in the kitchen—the door was closed—I saw no knife—when I was called back I believe they were chiefly the prosecutor's friends about him—the prisoner was without his cap the first time.

JOSEPH NASH. I am house-surgeon at the London Hospital—I examined the prosecutor's arm, and found an incised wound about an inch in length, and little more than that in depth—it must have been inflicted with a very sharp instrument—there was also a superficial wound at the back of the neck, I should say inflicted by the same instrument—the wound on the arm was such a one as would be received in parrying a blow—it was followed by inflammation and erysipelas, and was likely to have been very serious—as the man was of a bad habit of body.

Prisoner's Defence. I did not carry a knife about me at all; I was coming along, and the prosecutor and a lot of sailors were standing there—he sent a girl after me, who asked if I had any money—I said no, and told her to go home—two men then came and knocked me down, and took away my cap and handkerchief.

GUILTY. Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.

1930.
JAMES BEAR and
GEORGE BLERTON were indicted for
steal
ing at
St. James, Westminster, 1 snuff-box, value 2l., 1 purse, 9s., 1 sove
reign, 1 half-sovereign, 4 half-crowns, 11 shillings, 1 sixpence, and two 5l. Bank-notes; the property of
James Harmer Ivatts, their master, in his dwell
ing house.

JAMES HARMER IVATTS. I am a billiard-room keeper at 218, Regent-street. The prisoners lived in my service as errand-boys, and attended to the rooms and to the playing—I had a box in a drawer in the kitchen, containing a small box with the notes and money stated in the indictment—I went out on Sunday, the 25th of July, and left everything safe—I did not leave either of the prisoners on the premises—when I returned I found the kitchen door fastened inside with a chisel—I pushed it open, and found the box on the kitchen table, opened, and everything gone out of it—I went into the area, and found the steps placed against the gate, and the gate open—I called in a policeman, and the prisoners were afterwards taken—Bear said he was induced by Blerton to go down the area with him, and it was him that opened the box with the chisel.
Blerton. I did not force the box open, neither did I go down first.
Bear. You did; I was going down, and you pushed me down; you went into the kitchen, and forced the box open, and helped me to take the money out.
Blerton. It is false.

WILLIAM CARROLL. I am servant to Mr. Drummond Woolf, of Half-moon-street, Piccadilly. On Sunday, the 25th of July, I was walking with the prisoners up Regent-street—Bear left me, to go down to see if his master wanted him, and he went down the area—Blerton said, "We will stand here"—we stood on the other side of the railing, a little way off—I thought I heard the door open, and I said to Blerton, "What is that?"—he said, "It is the kitchen door"—presently Bear came, and called, "George"—Blerton went to him on the other side, and I saw him hand him a box—Blerton then got down, and I thought he lifted up a ladder—they then both came out, and ran across the road—I asked what they were running for; if they had been doing anything—they said, No, they were only running out of the way of the carriages—we went down by the corner of Hanover-square—Blerton turned to see if anybody was behind him—I said, "What have you been doing, have you been robbing the house?"—he said, "No," and he was going to punch my head for saying so—we got into Brook-street, and Blerton said, "I am going out of town"—I said, "What a storyteller you are; you said you had but 1s. 6d., and wanted to borrow something of me"—he said, "Yes, but Bear has been down and got some money"—he pulled out a box and gave Bear a sovereign and a half, and some silver—Bear had some silver before that—when we got into Curzon-street, Blerton said to me, "I will give you 30s. if you will change a bank-note for me where you change your master's checks"—I said, no, if it was stolen I should have to abide by the consequences—he said, "If you will, I will give you 30s. each"—I said, no, I would not—we got into some mews in Park-lane, and Blerton offered me a sovereign—I refused it, as I thought it had been stolen—Blerton took out a knife, and said he would stick it into my ribs if I ever said such a thing again—I did not receive the sovereign—I do not think this is the box that was taken—I thought it was a box with the corners rounded off, and larger—it was mounted in gold—I saw Blerton with two bank-notes.
Blerton. He did receive the sovereign, Bear gave it to him. Witness. Bear said he did not give it me, but that Blerton did; but I did not receive it.

Bear. We saw him at the bottom of Windmill-street; Blerton said we were going to rob our master, and he said he would get ready and come with us; he said he would go to the door and ring the bell, and if anybody an
swered it he would ask if a Mr. Brown lived there; he came, but nobody was in the house; we went down and opened the area door with a key, and he was to have a sovereign; I can prove that he did have a sovereign, and he took my little brother to the play with it, but he has kept him out of the way for fear he should talk about it. Witness. It is false, my mother went with me to the play.
Blerton. There is a here who can prove he had the sovereign, and that he said he would trump up a fine tale about us. Witness. I t is false.

JOHN GRAY (police-sergeant C 10.) I took Bear into custody in Great Windmill-street—I was in plain clothes—I told him I was a policeman, and that I took him for breaking into his master's house, and stealing a box con
taining notes and gold—I asked where the box was—he said it had been left under the pillow at a lodging-house at Wapping, where they slept on the Sunday night—I asked where the notes were changed—he said at Reading, and that there was another boy in it, named Carroll.
Bear. He did not take me; I was sitting up stairs, and knew my master was coming; I intended to give myself up; I left Blerton on the Saturday

night, and would not go with him any more. Witness. Bear's mother wen to the prosecutor and told him her son had returned from the country, on pur
pose to have him apprehended—they were away a fortnight—I have not traced the notes—nothing was found on them.

ANN WRIGHT. I found this tortoise-shell box in the bed at No. 75, New Gravel-lane, Shadwell, the morning after two young lads had come, and had a lodging there—it was empty—I cannot swear the prisoners were the lads.
The prisoners. We are the lads.
J. H. IVATTS re-examined. This is my tortoise-shell box, which contained the money—I lost altogether 14l. the purse and the key of a private room were thrown over Waterloo-bridge.
Bear. No, over Vauxhall-bridge.
Bear's Defence. I lived with my master at first about eight months ago; I then left him and came back; he knew that Blerton was a bad character, but never said anything about it, but put me with him.

Blerton's Defence. He did not know that I was a bad character, and if he speaks the truth he can give me a good character; I had lived with him before for a long while; I lived with him this time for about six months; we had 5s. a week, and had to work from nine in the morning till one, and one week I was up four whole nights attending to the billiard-table while my master was playing, and I had to put the score on for him to cheat a gentle
man; he won about 40l.

J. H. IVATTS re-examined. I deny the story—I do not play once in a month—I never won 40l. or 40s. at a time in my life, and as to the scoring, I have given them both cautions against that sort of thing.

Blerton. Yes, in the presence of gentleman, but not by ourselves; you won 14l. one night of a gentleman, and there were two or three others that you allowed to do the same thing, up in the top room, and in the middle room; Mr. Wigan and Mr. Thompson, don't you recollect? Witness. No, I do not; if I let a private room I do not know who is in it. Blerton. None know less than those that won't know. Witness. I know that he ran away from his ship and stole 25l., and I do not believe that Bear would have committed himself in this way without he had been induced by Blerton—my place is not a gambling-house, but a licensed place for the amusement of gentlemen—they very seldom play for money—these boys were to a certain extent acting as markers—they looked after the rooms and attended to the gentlemen when the bell rang—I am the owner of the house, and live in it, but I let the lower part—it is in the parish of St. James, Westminster.

WILLIAM CARROLL
re-examined. I went with the prisoners because they asked me to take a walk with them—I never received the sovereign—I gave information to the police next day.
Blerton. He did receive it; two boys in Angel-court could prove it, and you told them you knew it was stolen. Witness. It is no such thing.

JOHN GRAY
re-examined. I heard nothing from Carroll until I went to his master's house on the Monday, as Bear was apprehended on the Sunday—it was in consequence of Bear's stating that Carroll was concerned in it that I went there—he denied positively having received a sovereign, and I took him to the Mansion-house.

BEAR—
GUILTY. Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor —
Confined Six Months

BLERTON—
GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1931.
JOHN BURGESS was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Charles Payne.
MR. RYLAND conducted the Prosecution,

CHARLES PAYNE. I am apprenticed to a carpenter, and live in Great Wild-street, Lincoln's Inn-fields—on Wednesday, the 1st of July, between twelve and one O'clock, I was in Fleet-street, and saw the prisoner I was pass
ing him on the kerb, and he struck me in the eye with a stick, which cut my eye, and he then struck me twice on the wrist, and broke the bone of my wrist—I had not spoken to him or annoyed him in any way—he was taken into custody, and I was taken to the hospital, where I remained three weeks—I have pretty well go the use of my arm again—there were ten or more boys following the prisoner at the time, but I did not see them annoying him or say anything to him.

JAMES JOY (City-policeman, 347.) I saw the prisoner in Fleet-street, and some boys following him, but they were not annoying him in my presence—I cautioned them not to do so—he had this stick in his hand—I saw the prosecutor—he was not following or annoying the prisoner, but as he passed, the prisoner turned and struck him, as he described, over the eye, and three times over the arm—I took him to her hospital, as one of the bones of his arm was broken.

COURT. Q. Do you know anything of the prisoner? A. I know him about the streets, dressed in a very peculiar manner—the boys tease him—I did not see them do so on this occasion—I do not know how he gets his living—he was remanded for me to get a certificate from the surgeon—he is in his right state of mind.

JOHN BEMERSYDE HAY. I am house-surgeon at St. Bartholomew's Hos
pital—Payne was brought there on the 1st of July—one of the bones of his arm was broken—he went out on the 21st—he is quite well now.
Prisoner's Defence. The boys were annoying me and throwing stones at me, which caused me to use the stick.

GUILTY.*—
Confined Three Months,
and to enter into his recognizance in 20l. for three years

1932.
JAMES JOHNSON was indicted
for indecent acts and practices with one
John Robinson, not in custody.

GUILTY Aged 31.—
Confined One Year,
and to enter into his own recog
nizances in 40l. for seven years.

1933.
THOMAS DUGDALE was indicted
for unlawfully selling and publishing obscene prints.

GEORGE WILLIAM SHARP. I am clerk to Messrs. Pritchard and Collett, solicitors to the Society for the Suppression of Vice, No. 57, Lincoln's Inn
fields. On the 27th of July last, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, in consequence of instruction I received, I went to the station-house at Bow-street, and after being there searched by a policeman, I went to No. 51, Holywell-street, Strand, followed by the policeman—I went into the shop and asked for a book, which the prisoner showed me, and which I produce—I paid a guinea for it—I then left the shop, and went, closely followed by the policeman who had searched me, to the Society's chambers, where he took from my pocket the book I had bought of the defendant.

COURT. Q. Was it a public and open shop, that anybody might go into? A. Yes, there were prints of Venus, and all those sorts of things, in the window, to denote the nature of the traffic carried on inside.
Prisoner I deny that; I plead guilty to selling the book, and throw myself on the mercy of the Court.

WILLIAM CHADWICK (police-sergeant F 2.) On the 27th of July, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, I searched Mr. Sharp very strictly, and am certain he had then no book in his possession—I followed him to No. 51, Holywell-street—I never lost sight of him all the way—I was not five yards behind him—he went into the shop—I waited in view of the shop till he came out again, and then followed him to the Society's chambers, where I again searched him, and found this book in him—on the 20th of Aug. I received a warrant to arrest the prisoner—I went to his shop, and found him sitting there smoking his pipe—I was in my unigram—I took him into cus
tody—Mr. Davis, who was with me, searched the house, and seized some articles.

COLBY ATKINSON DAVIS. I am an officer of the Customs. On the 20th of Aug. I received instruction from the Commissioners of Customs, went to No. 51, Holywell-street, and searched the premises—I there found in a box, in the front bed-room, 377 pictures of the most obscene description—I pro
duce a part of them, the whole are in the Court, besides snuff-boxes and other things—it is the prisoner's residence—I have visited his shop several times before, and have seized books and other things before—I seize these things, on the part of the Customs, as French articles, not having paid the duty—I have no doubt of these being French goods—the snuff-boxes have false bottoms with screws—they were found in a box, of which the prisoner produced me the key from a drawer in the shop—the stock consisted of nothing but these kind of books to excite the passions, except one row of novels of about fifty volumes—these obscene works were lying alongside of Bibles and Prayer-books—the place was very poorly furnished up stairs—these pictures are brought over by the stewards of steam-boats—I once seized upwards of 30, 000 prints from the prisoner's brother, and from William Dugdale 12, 000 or 14, 000.

Prisoner's Defence. I am very poor, and am getting almost blind, and do not know what to turn to to get a living; I have got out of my own trade, which I am not able to follow; I was then engaged at my brother's till he dis
charged me; I have no desire to demoralize society; I whish to get my living comfortably and honourably.

GUILTY. Aged 26.—
Confined One Year,
and to enter into his own recognizance in 80l. for five years.

1934.
JANE WADSWORTH was indicted
for a like offence.

GEORGE WILLIAM SHARP. On the 13th of July, in consequence of in
struction I had received, after being searched at the station-house, I went to No. 20, Wych-street, Drury-lane—I went into the shop, saw the prisoner there, and asked for a book—I did not ask for it by name—I paid a guines for it, and left—the officer followed me, as before, to the Society's chambers, and took the book from me there—this is it.
WILLIAM CHADWICK (police-serjeant F 2.) On the 13th of July I searched Sharp at the station-house—he had no book on him then—I followed him to
Wych-street, and saw him go into NO. 20—he came out shortly afterwards—I followed him to the Society's chambers, where I again searched him, and took from him this book.

COLBY ATKINSON DAVIS. On the 20th of Aug., in consequence of direc
tions from the Commissioners of Customs, I went to No.20, Wych-street, and searched the house and shop—I found the prisoner there, up stairs—I seized two British books full of obscene prints, which the policeman brought away—the shop is kept by a person named Blacketer, who has just now come out of prison, where he has been three months for exposing these sort of things for sale in the window—the prisoner lives with him as his wife—this makes the fourth seizure I have made there—I never went there before without bringing away 100 or 150 of these books an pictures—we bring away the foreign, and the police take the British—as soon as I go into the shop and state what I want, he produce them I take them away, and in a few days they will begin again—these people are all leagued together, as soon as we go to one, they fly off to give notice to each other.
Prisoner's Defence. I am only a servant. I cannot say that I sold this book; I know I had two books stolen; it is my master's shop.

JAMES REEVES. I am a bookseller and news agent in Drury-lane. I am sent here by Mr. Blacketer, who is very ill in bed, to say that this person is only his servant, and that if anybody is liable it is himself—he wishes his servant to be cleared of this charge, as she has done it inadvertently—I have myself been six months in prison, not for selling prints, there was no sale, they could not produce the witness, he was gone to Dublin, but a party seized some in a friend's shop, where I happened to he at the time—I was not con
victed of keeping a shop for the sale of such things—I was convicted, certainly, but there was no foundation for it—it was entirely a fabrication—I have a charge of conspiracy and felony against this Mr. Davis.

GUILTY.—
Confined One Year.

1935.
WILLIAM HUMPHREYS
and
JOHN PHEASANT were in
dicted for
a conspiracy.

WILLIAM NICHOLSON, ESQ. I attend form the Crown-office of the Queen's Bench. I produce an indictment, preferred in the Queen's Bench against Thomas and Mary Twig, John and Sarah Wilson, and George and Mary Lane, for keeping a common brothel—the bill was found on the first count only—the witnesses on the back of the bill are John Pheasant and William Parsons—there is no other endorsement, therefore we assume that the witnesses are the prosecutors—I did not attend the Grand Jury on that occasion—I have the custody of the indictments pending there—warrants have been obtained, and the parties have appeared and pleaded—they applied for a summons, on account of no prosecutor's name appearing, and the whole proceeding being so extraordinary, and went before a Judge, who stayed the proceedings—(the summons was here handed in)—they could not give notice of trial in conse
quence of the not being able to serve the prosecutor—a prosecutor on an indict
ment of that sort does not enter into recognizance.

Humphreys. I served the notice on the attorney—we carried the indict
ment as far as possible, and Mr. Nicholson told me we could not do more till next Term. Witness. The hitch occurred when they could not serve notice of trial on the prosecutor.

WILLIAM EDWARD DREW. I come from the office of Clerk of the Peace for Middlesex—I produce an indictment, presented at the adjourned Session at Westminster, on the 16th of July—the names on the back of the bill are "John pheasant, of Bow-common, in the county of Middlesex, labourer," and "John Wormington"—I attended at that Session—I cannot tell whether Humphreys paid the fees on that occasion—I have no doubt of having seen him there—a Session seldom passes without my seeing him—I do not know Pheasant—the bill is against John Wooldridge, Frederick Annesley, Rose Joseph, Mary Smith, and Sarah Gale—there are two counts: one is for keeping a common bawdy-house—warrants have not been issued upon that—I believe some application was made to the Court—the course pursued by us is that the prosecutor shall enter into recognizance in 100l. before the warrant is allowed to go out of the office, and he has not entered into that recognizance.

MARY LANE. I am the daughter of John Lane, and live at No.6, Lazcnbury-court. On the 24th of April, between eight and nine o'clock is the evening, Humphreys called at our house and asked if Mr. or Mrs. Lane were at home—they were not, and I saw him—he said he had called to in
form my father and mother that they were under indictment, and that if we called on him at Mr. Delamere's office, 43, Lincoln's Inn-fields, we should receive every information, and that we hade nothing to fear—he said we were under indictment with two other houses of Twin's and Wilson's, and that he had been there and left his paper—I asked why he did not bring one to me, for I could not recollect all he had got to say, and I asked if he would be so kind as to put it down in writing—he said he would, and while I was getting him the pen, ink, and paper, I said, "I suppose you are aware that our house is not in the same parish; "I thought it was a parish concern—he turned round, looked at me, and told me not to ask him any more d—d questions; if I wanted further information I was to go to Mr. Delamere's office between eleven and twelve o'clock, or else go to the other houses and get information—I asked by whom we were indicted, and for what; and said we did not keep a disorderly house, or anything of the kind—he said it was Mr. Pheasant, of Bow, who had indicted us, but he could not tell us for what.

Humphreys. Q Will you swear that your's is not a disorderly house of the very worst description, where there are children of eleven or twelve years of age? A. I will—it is in the parish of St. Paul, Covent-garden—I am not to answer whether it is a common brothel—it is not an open house—we never let children in, neither do we keep any females.
COURT. Q. Did you ever see Pheasant at your house? A. Never, and I know every creature that enters it.

SARAH WILSON. I am the wife of John Wilson, and live at 29, Rose-street, Long-acre. On Saturday evening, the 24th of April, Humphreys called and left this paper with me, "W. H. Humphreys, at Mr. Delamere's 43, Lincoln's Inn-fields"—he said the house was under indictment, but if my husband would call on him on Monday morning, from eleven till twelve o'clock, things might be amicably arranged—he then said, "Good Night," and that was all—my husband does not keep any house jointly with Twig or Lane—he has nothing at all to do with it—they live at different places.

COURTS. Q. Do you know them? A. Only as neighbours—I am not aware of any ground for considering our house a brothel—he wished to extort money, and we did not think fit to give it him—ours is not a house that we were apprehensive of having indicted.
