On the 31st of July, about ten minutes before twelve o'clock at night, I was going my rounds, I saw a crate standing under a shed, and the prisoner near it—he had no business there—when I approached he left the crate hastily, and came towards me—I asked what he had been doing there—he said, "Nothing"—I said, "Let us come back and see"—we went, and I found a hole in the crate, the straw pulled on one side and disturbed, and down where he had stood were these two butter-pots—I accused him of stealing some—he said he was not stealing, but merely looking to see what the crate contained—I told him it was not on his beat, and if it were he had nothing to do with the

contents of it—I told him I should take him before the inspector, suspecting he had been stealing—he said, "Yes, I have," put his hand into his pocket and pulled out the top of one butter-pot, and begged for God Almighty's sake I would say nothing about it.

Cross-examined by MR. EVANS. Q. When you first saw him, where was he standing? A. By the crate—these butter-pots were close by the crate—the prisoner has been employed there twenty-one or twenty-two months—he is married and has a family—I do not know anything against him—I took him before the inspector—there was a further search made in his cupboard, and more things were found—he said he had found the whole on his beat, and he was looking into the crate to see what it contained.

WILLIAM SMITH. I am in the service of the Dock Company. I had seen the crate of crockery safe on Saturday afternoon the 31st of July, from two to four o'clock—I cannot say whether there was any hole in it—I did not examine it—I assisted in placing the crate under the shed—I did not notice any hole in it, or any straw protruding from it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Four Months

1961.
ELIJAH KEATES was indicted
for stealing 12 ounces of sugar, value 3d.; the goods of the
London Dock Company.

SAMUEL EGERTON (policeman H 193.) On the 1st of Aug. I was on duty in the London Docks—the prisoner was on duty as a constable there—he had been doing duty on the East-quay the night before—he came to the station—I followed him, and saw him go to his cupboard, unlock it, put his hand in, pull something out, put it into his hat, and put his hat on a shelf over the dresser in the kitchen—he then said he would go and buy something for his breakfast—he put on his hat and was going out—we met the inspector in the passage, I told him—he ordered the prisoner to pull his hat off, and in it was this sugar—the inspector asked him where he got it—he said he picked it up the other night as he was coming off duty on the North-quay.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. What time was this? A. Between seven and eight o'clock on Sunday morning—I was about a yard and a half behind him—I should say the cupboard is about a yard wide—he opened the door quite wide—I saw that plainly—there are six samples of sugar—he was in the same division as I am, and was engaged at the same place—his pay as a policeman as 18s. 7 1/2d. a week—he had been seven or eight months em
ployed in the docks.

GEORGE MADDOX. I am an inspector of police. I saw the prisoner's hat taken off, these samples were in it; he said he did not know what it was—I found it was sugar—he said he picked it up in the docks—it was his duty to take care of the property in the docks, and to report anything he found to me.

Cross-examined. Q. How are these things got at? A. These samples are nailed on the outside of each cask, with a nail through them, and are samples of what the sugar is in the cask—if he picked any of these up, it was his duty to bring them to me.
DANIEL RUDKINS. I am an officer of the Dock-Company. I know some sugars were landed partly damp, and a sample was drawn and nailed on the
cask till the sampling was completed—these would remain on the top till the lotting was completed.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Three Months

1962.
ALICE M'LEAN was indicted for
stealing 1 watch, value 8l.; the goods of
Frederick Leopold Slater, from his person; and
WILLIAM M'LEAN
as an accessory after the fact; Alice M' Lean having been before convicted of felony.

FREDERICK LEOPOLD SLATER. On the 25th of July, at half-past eleven o'clock, I was coming down the Commercial-road—Alice M' Lean and another female spoke to me, we went to a public-house and drank—we came out, they still stopped, and kept talking to me—the other woman then left—I felt for my watch, and it was gone—I said to Alice M' Lean, "You have been taking my watch"—she said, "No, it must be the old woman"—I said I would give her in charge—she begged and prayed, and went down on her knees, and said she would give me the watch—she took me down to Bluegate-fields, and said to an old woman there, "Will you go and see if Mr. So-and-So is there"—she went, came back, and said he was not—Alice M' Lean then ran to a door-way—I ran, caught her by the shoulder, just in the door-way, pulled her into the street, and called "Police!"—William M' Lean then came out, struck me, and knocked me down—I am sure the prisoners are the persons.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. There was another woman with Alice M' Lean? A. Yes—she was away when I missed my watch, and Alice M' Lean said she would try and find the old woman—I lost my watch in Sutton-street, not more than half a mile from where William M'Lean knocked me down—he said, "What are you doing with this woman?" and said he was a policeman.

WILLIAM CHARLES POTTER (policeman K 212.) I went to 4, Bluegate-fields, and found the two prisoners, and another man in bed—I said to Slater, "Which is it"—he said, "This is the man, and this is the woman"—the woman was undressed, the man had his coat off—I said they must go to the station, the woman for robbing Slater, and the man for striking him—the man said he never struck a man in his life—the woman was going to put on a bonnet and shawl that were there—Slater said, "It is no use your putting on that bonnet and shawl; this is the bonnet and shawl you had on before."
JAMES JOHN BLAKE (policeman K 137.) I produce a certificate of Alice M' Lean's former conviction—(read—Convicted on the 8th of May, 1843; and confined one year)—she is the person.

ALICE M'LEAN—
GUILTY. Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven years.

WILLIAM M'LEAN—
NOT GUILTY.

1963.
HENRY PAGE was indicted for
stealing 1 truck, value 3l.; the goods of
Henry Kent; and
JOSEPH POTTER
for feloniously and knowingly receiving the same; Page having been before convicted of felony; to which

PAGE pleaded
GUILTY.—
Confined One Year.

HENRY KENT. I live in Plummer's-place, Clerkenwell. On the 16th of Aug., Page hired a truck of me, and did not bring it back—I did not see him till the 28th of Aug., when he was taken by the policeman.
GEORGE CONNOR. (policeman G 72.) I took Page, for stealing the truck—he
said he was poor and but of work, and could not help it—I went to potter's, he said he had bought the truck for 10s.—it is worth 3l.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Page told out he sold it for 10s. to potter? A. Yes—it is an old truck.
RICHARD MOSS (policeman G 195.) I went to potter—he said he had bought the truck for 10s., that it was worth about 1l. 5s., and being a bargain he bought it.

POTTER—
NOT GUILTY.

1964.
JOHN EASTWICK was indicted for
stealing 1 peck of oats, value 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Guiver, his master; and
WILLIAM SHEARMAN
, for feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to be stolen.

THOMAS GUIVER. I am a coach-proprietor, at Cheshunt. I keep my horses at the Ship-inn, Tottenham—Eastwick was my horse-keeper there—I thought it necessary to put some marked papers amongst my oats—I have some oats here which have the papers amongst them.
Cross-examined by MR. PARNWELL. Q. Does Eastwick feed his horses at Tottenham? A. Yes—I bring up the oats, and he cuts his own chaff—he had been about five months in my service.

RICHARD SINCLAIR (policeman N 321.) I saw Mr. Guiver on the 14th of Aug., and I gave him some pieces of paper—on the morning of the 17th of Aug. I saw Shearman about the street—I watched, and saw him stop at the Ship, at Tottenham, about two o'clock in the morning—he remained there till about four o'clock—soon after he left I stooped his cart, and found these oats and this chaff—the papers were in the oats—I went and took Eastwick, on a charge of robbing his matter—he said he had not, he had only given Old Billy some sweepings—there were five pieces of paper found in the oats—I saw one piece picked out.
Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Is the Ship a regular coaching-house? A. Only Mr. Guiver's horses feed there—other horses stop there—there is one ostler employed by the publican.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you understand who he meant by Old Billy? A. I know Shearman goes by that name—I have known him some years—he said he was seventy-eight years old—I never heard anything particular against him—I had him in custody once about a macintosh—he was in company with a woman that had it—he was discharged, and examined as a witness.
(Eastwick received a good character.)

EASTWICK—
GUILTY.—
Confined Six months.

SHEARMAN—
GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Three Months.

1965.
FREDERICK GROVES and
CHRISTOPHER SAUNDERS were indicted for
stealing 2 sixpences; the moneys of
James Parham, their master.

JAMES PARHAM. I am a pork-butcher, in the Broadway, Westminster; the prisoners were in my employ. On the 16th of August I thought it necessary to send for a policeman—I marked two sixpences and some other money, and I gave the sixpences to a neighbour, who is not here—I watched the prisoners through a hole in the floor, and I saw Groves take five shillings; three shillings he put into his pocket, and one shilling in the paper-drawer—he then gave Saunders three sixpences from the till, to get a pint of beer—he had no business with any sixpences from the till; there were plenty of
halfpence—the beer came to 3d.—one of those sixpences was marked—Saunders went and brought back three penny-pieces—two sixpences were gone.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Groves had been some months in your employ? A. Yes; five months the last time, and Saunders has been three weeks—I am sure Groves took out three sixpences; I saw him take up one at time.

.
ROBERT WRIGHT (policeman B 99.) A female sent me to the prose
cutor's—he gave the prisoners in charge—he told me that they had robbed him—I searched Groves; while I was doing so, Saunders gave up the money to Mr. Parham.

JAMES PARHAM
re-examined. Saunders gave up one of the marked sixpences to me, and one other, which he said belonged to me.

Cross-examined. Q. When you accused him, he gave you the money directly? A. Not directly; I said it was no use denying it—one prisoner was on one side of the counter, the other on the other—it was at super-time.
(Saunders received a good character.)

GROVES
GUILTY. Aged 25.—
Confined One Year

SAUNDERS
GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoners.)

1966.
MARY CAIN was indicted
for stealing a jacket, a pair of trowsers, 4 waistcoats, and other articles, value 5l.; the goods of
Leonard Hoey.

LEONARD HOEY. I am a seaman, and live at the Cock public-house, Tothill-street, Westminster. On the 19th of July I had a bag of clothes, containing the articles stated—they were safe that morning, and in the even
ing they were gone—on the Wednesday week afterwards the prisoners came into the public-house, and offered the buttons for sale for a pot of beer—she left them with the landlord's son; they were in a piece of paper in her hand—they had been in the pocket of the waistcoat I lost—I went to her apartment and found several duplicates, one of which related to my shirt and waistcoat—these are them.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. who was sleeping in the room with you? A. They were strangers—there might be half-a-dozen persons in the public-house when the prisoner came in with the buttons.
WILLIAM MILLERMAN (policeman B 95.) I went to the prisoner's house—she said it was her place—I there found this duplicate of a waistcoat and shirt, pawned at Mr. Arnold's.

GEORGE PARSONS. I am assistant to Mr. Arnold, a pawnbroker. I pro
duce this shirt and waistcoat, they were pawned by a woman—I have a duplicate like this produced by the officer; it is dated the 20th of July.
EDWARD THORN. I keep the public-house—the prisoner was in the habit of coming there—she left these buttons with my son.

1967.
SARAH HOLLAND was indicted
for stealing 1 shilling; the money of
Charles Arnold, her master.

CHARLES ARNOLD. I keep a shop, at No. 42, High-street, Islington—the prisoner was in my service. On the 18th of August I went to bed, and left some money in my till—the prisoner had the key of my shop—the till was open the next morning I missed a shilling from the till, and charged
her with having taken it—she said had not, but said she could give me a shilling—she gave me this one, it is the one I had marked, and missed from the till that morning.

GUILTY.—
Confined One Month.

1968.
JOHN STRIDE RIPLEY was indicted
for stealing 2 handker
chiefs, 2s.; 2 pairs of gloves, 1s. 6d.; 1 oz. of pins, 3d.; and 1 brooch, value 1s.; the goods of
Robert Eames Gear, his master.

ROBERT EAMES GEAR. I am a linendraper, and live in Seymour-place, Camden-town. The prisoner was my apprentice—I received 40l. with him—he came to me about four months ago—in consequence of something, I sent for a policeman, and gave him into custody—his box was produced an opened—two pairs of silk gloves, two handkerchiefs, and a brooch were found in it; which were my property—he had not the least right to take them—he took hold of my arm, and said, "Forgive me for this offence; it has been the first time, my father will pay for all.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. His box was unlocked? A. Yes; and was in a place where there were other boxes; a place that every-body in my employ went to—it was no room; it was a lobby—the policeman asked the prisoner if he had any objection to have his box searched—he made no reply then; he afterward said, "No"—he fetched it after the policeman had asked him two or three times for it—I have three persons in my employ—one has served me as an apprentice, and is with me for another three years—I have three beside the prisoner—I advertised for an apprentice, and his father applied to me in consequence—I have had the 40l.—his father made a remark about paying half of it—I wished to have it all, and got it.

Q. I believe his father called on you a short time before this? A. Not a short time—I did not give him a good account of the prisoner—I said he was of a bad temper, and that that was the only fault that was in him.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. At the time the father called on you, had you any reason to suspect the boy's honesty? A. No—I had no desire to get rid of him, and found no fault—what gave me a suspicion was his taking glove-boxes out of my shop.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you see him take them? A. No, but he ac
knowledged it—here are two letters, which are in his writing—they were left in the front room over the shop, one directed to me, and one to my wife, on the 20th of June, or thereabouts—they do not refer to anything in this indictment.

SAMUEL GILLMAN (policeman S 76.) I was called in, and the prisoner was given into my custody—he brought in his box himself, from a place adjoining the room where we were standing—these are the articles that were found, two pairs of gloves, two handkerchiefs, and a brooch—and a paper of pins was found on his person at the station—when he came to the gloves, Mr. Gear said, "Where did you get these?"—he said he got these on Mon
day last, and this other pair he said his mother gave him—Mr. Gear found his own mark on them—when he came to the brooch, he said it was his master's property—as he was going out of the room to put his hat on, he took hold of his master's arm, and said, "Forgive me, my father will pay for all."
Cross-examined. Q. When you proposed to look at his box, he said he

had no objection, and he brought the box in his own hands to his master? A. Exactly so—he opened it, it appeared to be unlocked—he said he got these gloves on the Monday—I do not recollect saying that before—I will not swear whether I said before that he said the other pair was given him by his mother, or he said the brooch was his master's or that he said, "For
give me, my father will pay for all."

MR. PRENDERGAST to MR. GEAR. Q. Is this a brooch you wore? A. No—I should sell it in my shop for a shilling—there are many houses which sell these brooches—I have only two like this, and they are not the same pattern and color—I do not know whether this is stone or glass—these are the gloves—they were just in this way—this pair appear to have been worn—I saw them in the prisoner's hat on Sunday, with my mark on them—I did not speak to him about them then—I sent for the policeman on Thursday morning—these white gloves are new.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you believe them to be your property? A. Yes, they have a mark on them—I have no doubt the whole are mine.
ESSEX CASES.

1969.
HENRY COOPER was indicted
for stealing a set of harness, value 1l.; and 1 pair of hames, value 2s. 6d.; the property of
George Lamert; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 37.—
Confined Six Months.

1970.
MARIA SMITH was indicted
for stealing 1 gown, value 2s. 6d.; 3 handkerchiefs, 1s. yard of ribbon, 3d.; 2 tippets, 1s.; 1 1/2 yards of holland, 6d.; 1 blind, 3d.; 3 yards of calico, 1s.; and 2 yards of cloth, 1s.; the property of
Thomas Arnold, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

1971.
ANN SULLIVAN was indicted
for breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Hammond, at Westham, and stealing therein 2 half-crowns; and 1 apron, value 5s. 6d.; her property; having been before con
victed of felony.

MARY HAMMOND. I live in the Almshouses, at Westham—on the 20th of Julty I lost an apron and two half-crowns—the apron has not been found, it was on my table, and the half-crowns in a box in the table drawer.

ANN ESSEX. On the 20th of July I was looking out of window, and saw Mrs. Hammond go out—the prisoner was standing at the corner of the turn
ing—she then went and tried Mrs. Hammond's door, then opened the window—a gentleman was standing there—when he went away she got in at the window—I went and saw her inside—she came out, and I asked her what she was doing inside—she said she was not inside—I said I had seen her—she called me a d—d liar, and went away.

HANNAH HARRINGTON. On the 20th of July, at five or six o'clock in the morning, I was putting something out—I saw the prisoner in the privy, fast asleep—I went down again afterwards, and she was walking backwards and
forwards at the back of the Almshouses—she then came and seated herself on the tombstone for some time—when I went out she sat with her back towards the gate and her hands behind her.
THOMAS FORRESTER (policeman K 229.) I took the prisoner, and charged her with this robbery—she said she had not committed it; that she did not go in at the window.
Prisoner's Defence. I was an out-patient of the London Hospital; I was going home, and this policeman followed and took me in charge.

CHARLES COLLIER (policeman K 30.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction—(read—Convicted 15th June, 1846, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 47.—
Confined One Year.

1972.
SARAH GRANGER was indicted
for unlawfully attempting to drown herself.

GEORGE FREEBODY. I live at Stratford, and work for Mr. Tanner—on the 26th of July, about six o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner struggling with another woman—she got away from her, and jumped into the river Lea—I saw her go under water, jumped in, and took her out—I had never seen her before—I am sure she is the person.
JURY. Q. How deep was it? A. About four feet six or eight inches—she jumped from a place as high as I am, and went right under.

MARY BEACHLEY. On the 26th of July, in the afternoon, I was with the prisoner at the Green Man—her husband came up, and I heard words pass between them directly—she upbraided him with forbidding her to see her child—they had many words, but I did not hear all—she was in a very ex
cited state—she had been drinking previous to coming to Stratford—her hus
band and her walked on towards the river, which was in his way to his mother's, where his business took him—they parted, and she said she would drown herself—I reasoned with her as long as I could, and held her as long as I was able, but she got away from me, and jumped into the water—I do not believe she was conscious of right or wrong at the time, from the state of excitement she was in.

Prisoner. You were in liquor yourself; I accidentally fell in; I rolled out of your arms and fell in. Witness. I have stated the truth—I was sent for, not to drink, but to try to prevail on the mother to allow the prisoner to see her child—she promised me if she could see her child for a few minutes she would return home peaceably—she is separated both from her husband and child—the child is four years old.

GEORGE WIGGENS (policeman.) About half-past six on this evening I went to the river and found a man had just taken the prisoner out of the water—she was very much excited, and had been drinking a little, but not so much as not to know what she was about—she was insensible for a minute or two after she was taken out—I took her to the house, her husband came to the door—I asked for admittance, he slung to the door, and said she should not come in—he came out, struck me, and told me I might take her where I liked—I got another constable, and we took her to the station in a truck.

Prisoner's Defence. I came from London to see my little girl, and to take her out for a couple of hours; they would not let me have her; I was drinking at a public-house with the witness; we afterwards went away, but returned to the beer-shop again; I was very much in liquor, and did not know that I saw
my husband; I was told I was not sensible for a long time after I was taken out.

p.rs: GUILTY Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—

div1.p:
1973.
ELIZA HUTCHINSON was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 6d., 6 sovereigns, 1 half sovereign, and 2 sixpences; the goods of
Thomas Aspling, having been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS ASPLING. I am seaman, and live at North Shields. On the 1st of July, about ten o'clock at night, I was at a public-house at Deptford, drinking with two other men—I saw the prisoner and some other women there—I do not know what public-house it was—I was sober, but had been drink
ing—I left the public-house with the prisoner and another girl, and the two men, and they went with me to get a lodging—I walked along by myself—we went to a house in Dock-street, Deptford—we got there about eleven o'clock—we all went in together—I had some beer there—I was sober after drinking that—I had six sovereigns, a half-sovereign, and two sixpences, in a purse in my jacket pocket—I slept in that house alone—the prisoner was in the room when I went to bed, nobody else—I laid my jacket on two chairs in the room—she was in the room then—I went to sleep—I was awoke about half an hour afterwards by the mistress of the house, she told me something, in con
sequence of which I felt in my jacket pocket, and missed my purse and money—I am quite sure it was in my jacket when I put it on the chair—this now produced is the purse which the money was in, it is mine—the prisoner was not in the room when I awoke—a witness showed me the purse—it had no money in it then.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you say you could not pay me till morning? A. No—I was not drunk—I did not drink any rum—we did not have six pots of ale and half-and-half—I did not give you the money to mind till morning, you took it from my jacket pocket—I did not count it out in my hand when I was going to put it into my pocket, and say, "You may as well take it as me"—I drank nothing but beer.

WILLIAM THOMAS ARTHUR (policeman R 202). On the 2nd of July, about one o'clock in the morning, I was on duty at Deptford, and saw some one running round the orchard as I was coming up King-street—I ran round to the other end of the orchard and met the prisoner—I knew her, and called her by name—she directly turned round as though some one had been assaulting her, made use of bad language, and said, "Now, Mr. Shelly, come and strike me again; I have assistance now; here is the police"—I judged from what she said, that somebody was after her, but saw nobody—I asked her the reason, and she told me it was Shelly and his woman—I said, "You shall not be assaulted, or anything of the sort"—I could see no one, and asked where they were—she said at a public-house where they had been drinking—as soon as I got into Dock-street, Deptford, the woman that keeps the house called after me to know if I had anybody in custody—I had the prisoner with me at the time—she could hear what the woman said—I said, "This is quite a different thing altogether"—I took her to the prosecutor, he directly said that was the girl; that he had been

robbed of nearly 7l. by her—the landlady said that being a stranger to the house, and finding she had gone out and left the man, she thought something was wrong—the prisoner said she had not robbed the man—I took hold of her left hand, which she had got very tightly clenched, and felt there was coin of some sort in it—she resisted very much indeed, and I was obliged to get other parties to assist me—I found a sovereign, a half sovereign and two sixpences in her hand—she said it had been given to her by Batty Conder—there is such a man—she did not tell me he was the person who had given her the money to take care of for him—I asked her where the purse was—she strongly denied any knowledge of having the purse.

Prisoner. I was not three yards from the house; you asked me what was the matter; I said a man of the name of Shelly and his woman had been blowing me up for what I was not guilty of: you said, "Come along with me, you shall not he insulted;" did not you? Witness. Yes—it was right round at the back part of the orchard—you were without your bonnet—you did not come towards the house till you were taken—you were not drunk.

SARAH EVERLY. I am the wife of John Everly, and live at the station-house, in the Greenwich-road—between one and two o'clock in the morning in question, I was desired to search the prisoner—she was very reluctant to be searched, and said she had nothing whatever about her—I found a purse in her bosom—she said it was her own, that she kept it to keep duplicates in, and said there were two in it then, but it was quite empty—it was shown to the prosecutor.
Prisoner. Q. Did not I say, if I had got a purse it was the one I kept my tickets in; and when you found it, I said, "That is my own?" A. No, you said the duplicate were there.

Prisoner's Defence. The man gave me the money to mind till the morning, and I took it, as I was drunk and he was drunk; he said, "We wen't go to bed till we have had a drop more rum, bring half a pint;" he said, "Get it in a half-pint bottle for 1s.;" I went to the first public-house, and could not get anything to drink; that was when I stood and saw the policeman; I was coming towards the house again; I did not attempt to run away; I no friends.

WILLIAM FREDERICK SEELEY. I was formerly in the police—I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted April, 1845, of larceny from the person, and confined one year)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person.

1974.
ISABELL SINGLETON was indicted
for stealing 2 shawls, value 1l.; and 1 apron, 2d.; the goods of
Susannah Flower; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

1975.
WILLIAM HENRY HORNBY was indicted for
unlawfully laying his hands on Frederick Williams, with intent to commit b— —y; and
FREDERICK WILLIAMS unlawfully consenting thereto—2nd COUNT, for unlawfully meeting together, with intent, &c.
The prisoners received good characters.

HORNBY
GUILTY on 2nd Count. —
Confined Twelve Months.

WILLIAMS
GUILTY on 2nd Count. —
Confined Six Months.

1976.
ANN HARRISS was indicted
for stealing 1 5l. Bank-note, the monies of
Thomas Whitewood, her master.

MARTHA WHITEWOOD. I am the wife of Thomas Whitewood, of South-street, Greenwich—the prisoner was in my service. On the 9th of Aug., a gentleman called to pay me some rent—he paid me a 5l. note and 17l. in silver—I put it all into a pocket-book, and placed it in a sideboard-drawer, in the parlour—the prisoner knew of it—I said before her that I had received it—she had access to the room—the drawer was left open—next day I placed the pocket-book under lock and key, without examining it—I do not know whether the note was in it then or not—next day, Wednesday the 11th, I went to the pocket-book, and missed the 5l. note and 3s.—nobody but the prisoner and my daughter knew anything about it—a constable was sent for, and the prisoner said, in my presence, she had not seen it—on Friday, the 13th, she came into the kichen, and asked me if I would forgive her if she paid me back the whole of the money—I asked her if she took the money—she said, "No"—I said, "Can I receive of you what you say you have never taken of me? No, I cannot do it"—in about a minute she came again, begged me to forgive her, and said she had taken the note and 3s.—I had told her that day, that if she had been tempted to take it, if she would replaced it, I would forgive her—I said nothing about her confessing, only about replacing the money—I sent for a policeman in the evening, and gave her in charge for something else—she is an orphan—I had no character with her—mine is the first place she has been at.

GEORGE GOODE. I took the prisoner on Friday evening at Mr. White
wood's—I told her she was charged with stealing a 5l. note—I cautioned her that I should tell the Magistrate what she said—she was anxious to tell the truth, and said she had taken the note and burnt it, and had taken other things besides.

Prisoner. I am guilty.
GUILTY

1977.
ANN HARRISS was again indicted
for stealing 1 pair of ear-rings, value 5s.; 3 yards of satin, 5s.; and 2 1/2 yards of silk, 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Whitewood, her master.

MARTHA WHITEWOOD. I missed a pair of ear-rings, and two pieces of satin—I knew nothing about these things when I said I would forgive the prisoner if she replaced the note—she said she said had taken the ear-ring, and I should find them at Foy's, at Deptford, with a few more things—I went there and found them—I did not miss the satin until she acknowledged taking it.
GEORGE GOODE. I produce a pair of ear-ring which I got at Mr. Foy's in Collier-street, Deptford.
MRS. WHITEWOOD re-examined. These are my ear-rings—they were lost from an ornament on the fire-place in the parlour.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix.

div1.p:
1978.
WILLIAM JENKINS was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin.

HANNAH DROUET. My husband is a licensed victualler, and lives in Hon-lane, Woolwich—on the 3rd of June, between nine and ten o'clock at night, the prisoner came and asked for a small glass of spruce—it came to 1d.—he

gave me a shilling—I gave him the change—he went away—I put the shilling into the till—I am quite sure there was no other shilling there—I looked particularly at it, and said I did not think it was good—the prisoner said yes, it was a good one—I sounded it—Gladwin the policeman came in and asked me to allow him to look at the shilling—I gave it him—when I took it out of the, I still found it was the only shilling there—I marked it and gave it the officer—this is it.
WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman R 122.) I saw the prisoner in Mrs. Drouet's house—she gave me this shilling.

JAMES WATSON. I keep the While Horse, at Charlton—on the 4th of June, about nine o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came to my house and asked for a pennyworth of spruce—I served him—he tendered me a piece of money purporting to be a shilling—I gave him a 6d. and 5d. in coppers, in change—he left the house—my ostler stood behind me and said, "I have a suspicion that this is a passer of bad money, he has been here before"—I never put the shilling out of my hand—I sent my son and the ostler after the prisoner for a mile, and I followed leisurely after them as far as a toll-gate—in a quarter of an hour I saw the prisoner again—he had avoided the main road—I took him coming through the gate—I said, "Young man, you have been to my house and passed a bad shilling for a pennyworth of spruce"—he denied being at my house at all, and did not know me—I took him back to my house—on the road he asked me to let him look at the shilling—I said, "No, I have got the shilling, you must give a better account of yourself"—he asked me to give it him back, and said he would give me a good one.

HENRY WADLOW (policeman R 267.) On the 4th of June I apprehended the prisoner at Mr. Watson's—I produce this bad shilling, which I received from Mr. Watson—I found on the prisoner a shilling, a sixpence, and five
pence in halfpence, all good—he said he had not been in the town more than two hours.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You questioned him about having been at Mr. Watson's, and he said afterwards he had been there? A. Yes—this case has been standing over for two months.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These shillings are both counterfeit, and have been cast in one mould.

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined Four Months.

1979.
JOHN WILLIAMS was indicted
for embezzlement.

ROBERT WILLIAMS. I am cashier in the service of Thomas Wilkinson Kershaw and another. They live at Greenwich; the prisoner was in their service—on the 5th of July I made a communication to my master, and in consequence of that six penny pieces, and twelve halfpence were marked—about four or five o'clock that evening I saw the prisoner serving a customer—he called for change for a shilling, and farthings—I took him five pence, one halfpenny, two farthings, and a sixpence—I did not see what he took from the customer—I think it was three farthings—he put it into the till, and went to another customer and sold her a yard of calico for 4 1/2d.—he called for change for sixpence—I saw him take 4 1/2d. of the customer—I watched him—he only put a portion of it into the till—I could not see how much, but I saw part of it in his hand—he went to another part of the counter, put up some hose, put his hand behind him, and dropped some of the coppers from his hand into his coat pocket—I think it was more than one piece—an officer was sent for.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Have you had any conversation with the customer? A. No—the customer is not here—when the prisoner dropped the money into the till I was at my desk, which is higher, and about a yard and a half from the till—I am not always there, but there is always some one there, except when they go to take change—I was about three yards distant from the prisoner when I saw him drop something into his pocket.

ANDREW NESBIT. I am in the prosecutor's employ—on the 5th of July I marked twelve halfpence and six penny pieces—the prisoner asked for change—the cashier left the desk and gave it him—I requested that he should come away from the till—I noticed the prisoner go to the till and drop something into it—he then went to another part of the shop, put his hand be
hind his back to his back to his coat-tail-pocket, and dropped some money into it—I com
municated what I had seen to Mr. Lowe—the prisoner was taken up stairs—Mr. Lowe requested him to put the money out that he had in his pocket—he did so, and there was 1s. 4 1/2d. in coppers—amongst it was one penny, and, I think two halfpence marked—Mr. Lowe accused him of robbing him—he said he had not—I pointed out the marked money to him—he made no reply—he had no business with that marked money in his pocket—he could not by right have put any money he received into his pocket.

Cross-examined. Q. How near were you to the till? A. Within about two yards, and I was about the same distance from the prisoner when he dropped the money into his pocket—to the best of my knowledge that was the same pocket from which he took the money afterwards.

JURY to ROBERT WILLIAMS. Q. Was the prisoner in the habit of bring
ing you the money? A. No—if he wanted any change he called for it—we do not check under sixpence—if he takes under sixpence he puts it into the copper till—if a customer comes and the prisoner calls for change, I take him the full change—he took 4 1/2d. from the customer, he should have put it into the copper till—I saw him hold some of the money after the customer was gone—if he took 7 1/2d. from a customer he would give me the sixpence.

GUILTY. Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months.

1980.
HENRY BANKS was indicted
for stealing I tobacco-box, value 1l. 15s.; 1 handkerchief, 3s.; 1 ring, 10s.; 5 sixpences, and 20 groats; the property of
Thomas Henry Record; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 31.—
Confined Three Months

1981.
GEORGE FAIRWAY was indicted
for stealing 4 loaves, value 1s. 9d.; the goods of
William Floyd; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

1982.
ROBERT BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 1d.; 3 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, and 2 half-crowns; the property of
George Moffat.

GEORGE MOFFATT. I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery. On the 13th of July I went to bathe at Plumstead, I laid my clothes on the ground, near a tree—I had in my pocket a purse in which was three sovereigns, two half-sovereigns, and two half-crowns—when I got out of the water my purse and money were gone, my pockets were empty—my attention was called to a small piece of paper lying beside my clothes—this is it.
THOMAS KNIGHT. I am a sergeant in the Artillery. I went with Moffatt

that day—the prisoner was there with a second party, he did not bathe—he went with me and a comrade to London—he had plenty of money, he spent about 9s.—I saw this piece of paper picked up by Moffatt—it is part of an answer to a latter—(read—"I received your letter, and you wanted to know the reason your wife did not answer your letters; I went to her, and she said she—")

MARY DOUDE. I am servant at the Duchess of Wellington. On the 14th of July, between six and seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came out of a room at our house, and gave me two sovereigns, and 14s. 6d.—he told me to take care of it.
FERRAND BROOK GIRLING. On Wednesday evening, the 14th of July, a person came to me and bought this ring for 13s.—I believe it was the prisoner.
Prisoner. He said before the Magistrate he did not allow me.

THOMAS GRIEVE. I am a private in the Artillery—I have written letters to the prisoner from his wife—I know this piece of a letter—I wrote it to the prisoner—I was at the bathing place that day—the prisoner wanted to leave the ranks—the bombardier would not let him go, he asked two or three times—we marched up to the front of the barracks, and stopped a quarter-of-an-hour or twenty minutes and a non-commissioned officer came and told the corporal we were to be detained—we were marched into the rear—the pri
soner saw his comrades getting searched, and put something into his nouth—he said it was tobacco, but I can swear it was not—he left the ranks without being searched, and went out of the back-yard.
MICHAEL GARVEY (policeman R 87.) I took the prisoner—I found on him this gold ring, one penny, one half-penny, a snuff-box, two purses, and an envelope box.

p.hi: The prisoner put in a written defence, declaring his innocence, and stating that part of the money was given him by his cousin, and part he had earned in his trade as a shoemaker; and that, being in liquor, he left it at the public-house for safety; that he afterwards took part of it out, and bought a ring and purse with it.

div1.p:
GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1983.
JOHN LLOYD was indicted
for embezzling the sums of 10s. 4d., 15s.. 5 3/4#172; d., and 9s., which he had received on account of
George Roffey, his master; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 33.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1984.
JOHN CROUT,
WILLIAM HARMAN , and
RICHARD ADAMS were indicted for
unlawfully having in their possession c. rtain naval stores, the property of
our Lady the Queen,

WILLIAM KENDALL. I am a private in the Royal Marines, stationed at Woolwich Dockyard—on Friday evening, the 30th of July, about half-past seven o'clock, I saw the prisoners in a small boat, alongside the pin
nace, in the river—they were shifting things from the boat to the pinnace, and from the pinnace to a barge, it was canvas, rope, and metal of some descrip
tion—the men were first in one boat and then in another—I gave information to Ellis, and he and I watched them—I saw one of the prisoner with a shovel—he appeared to be digging a hole in the ashes, and putting rope and canvas in the hole—they were all three in the barge at the time—I was on the

wharf at the dockyard, about a hundred yards from them—my attention was directed to a copper-pot in the after part of the small boat that I first saw them in—I afterwards saw it in the barge, thrown on the top of the ashes—the barge was placed under my care at three o'clock in the morning—I then found in it an oar, a pot, a block, some rope and canvas, and half a barrel of pitch on the ashes.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You saw this copper-pot first in the boat? A. Yes—I did not see it in the barge for eight or none hours after—I do not know whether other persons had been in the barge—there was a policeman in charge of it—I was relieved at nine o'clock, and another sentinel placed there—I had stood and looked at what was going on—I saw everything distinctly—I saw them all three in their turn shifting the canvas and rope—I saw that from where I was standing—it is my duty to watch—I saw a bread bag removed, and what appeared to be metal.

STEPHEN ELLIS (policeman R 162.) I am employed at Woolwich Dock-yard—on Friday evening, the 30th of July, about half-past seven o'clock, Kendall gave me information, and my attention was directed to a boat along
side of a barge—there were three persons in it; Court was one, I knew him—I cannot speak positively to the others—I saw them take something from the boat and put it on board the barge—I suspected it was not right—the three persons then left the barge, got into the boat, and rowed it to the Bell Water-gate pier—I ran round, and saw Court in the boat, which belonged to him; it had his name on it—the other two prisoners left the boat, and got on the pier, and Court was handing them some things which appeared to be sailors' clothing—I asked them what they had got, they said property they had brought from the Spiteful steamer—I asked them their names—they gave the same names that they did afterwards to the Magistrate—I am quite sure the prisoners are the persons.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you take them into custody then? A. No, they were taken the next day—i had never seen Adams before, to my knowledge—he gave the name of Henry Adams, and when he came before the Magis
trate, he gave the name of Richard Adams—I am sure he is the same man.

WILLIAM JAMES BUDD (police-inspector.) I was on duty at Woolwich Dockyard, on the 30th of July—some information was given me, and I called on Sergeant Glascock and Turner to go on board a barge—I went on board about eight o'clock, and found a great many ashes, some rope, canvas, copper sheathing, and a piece of copper bolt, in a corner of the barge; and a great many clews and lashing in the force part of the barge—they could not well cover them, there were so many—these produced are the articles—there was this pot and this pipe, and this sheet-copper—I then left the barge in possession of the constable—this is the canvas and rope.

Cross-examined. Q. Is this the greater portion of the canvas? A. I think about half of it—there was something alongside the barge, which is used for putting ashes into, previous to bringing them to the barge—the barge was at anchor about one hundred yards from the shore—there was nothing between that and the wharf.

JOHN EDWARD GLASCOCK (police-sergeant R 25.) I was on duty at Woolwich Dockyard, on Monday morning, the 30th of July, about eight or nine o'clock—I searched the barge which kendall pointed out—I had seen it several times previous—I first saw it about eight o'clock on Friday night, the 30th of July—Turner was left on board of it—I searched amongst the ashes, and had them all turned over—I found ninety clews and half a

barrel of pitch, a bread-bag, an oar, an eleven inch block, and a number of things, some of which have the Government mark—here is the broad arrow on the bread-bag, here is the worsted in the rope, but it cannot be seen before you open it, you can see nothing outside—I found a great deal of iron, some of it is marked, this sheathing is all marked, this block has the broad arrow on it.

DAVID ROY. I am a clerk in the Store-keeper's office at Woolwich—I have examined this property produced—this piece of copper is her Majesty's property, it is marked with the broad arrow, and this copper-pot also—this block is marked very distinctly—this sheathing has the broad arrow on it, the Government mark—this oar is marked, and this lashing is marked with the worsted thread—you can see it outside this.

JURY. Q. Are these marks generally known to every man on the river? A. Yes, very well known—this is all her Majesty's property—whoever is accustomed to get a living on the water, would know these marks very well.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoners were employed by the contractor to remove things from steamers? A. Yes—ashes, and rubbish of every kind—Mr. Warren Hawker has been the contractor about eight or nine months—these things are stamped—I identify them from the particular form of mark—if you were to put an arrow mark on that brief, I should say it was the Govern
ment mark—the prisoners are only common labourers—it is not the duty of the contractor to take anything but ashes and dust—I am not aware that many things found in the dust and ashes, have been returned—it is arranged that if any little things are found they are to be returned—I am not aware of any being returned.
COURT Q. They do not include these oars amongst dust and ashes? A. No.

COURT—
GUILTY. Aged 43.

HARMAN—
GUILTY. Aged 34.

ADAMS—
GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined One Month
, and
fined 5s.

1985.
JOHN DANIELS,
THOMAS MOON,
JOHN JACKSON WIL
LIAMS,
GEORGE ANGOVE , and
PATRICK CALLAGHAN , were indicted for
unlawfully having in their possession certain naval stores, the goods of
our Lady the Queen.

WILLIAM TURNER (policeman R 56.) I was on duty at Woolwich Dockyard on Friday evening, the 30th of July, at the Watergate—my attention was drawn to the prisoner Daniels, who was on the upper deck of the ship called the Nymph, which was lying in the stream opposite the dockyard—she is a hulk, for the accommodation of seamen while ships are fitting out—the Spite
ful steamboat was lying alongside the Nymph—the men on board the Spiteful had been paid off the some day, and there were none on board—I saw Daniels passing some rope and canvas down the accommodation-ladder of the Nymph into a boat, which was between the two vessels, moored at the bot
tom of the gangway, alongside of the Nymph—I saw one man in the boat, but I cannot say who it was, he appeared to be assisting in putting the things into the boat—I then procured the assistance of Sergeant Glascock, and went to pursue the prisoners in a boat—I had noticed Daniels get into the boat, and about ten minutes before the boat left, I noticed that there were four other men in it—when I got near to the boat I saw the prisoner Daniels in it, the four rowers, a female, and a man who is boatswain of the Spiteful steam-ship—they

landed the two passengers at the Bell Water-gate—there had been no opportunity for anybody to have got into the boat from the time I noticed Daniels handing the things down—whoever was in the boat must have been in it at the time I noticed it originally—I followed the boat with Glascock—it first went to Bell Water-gate, Woolwich, where the female and the boatswain landed—I then called to Daniels, I did not know his name—I called to the persons in the boat, and told them to stop and return, that I might see what property they had got in the boat—I got no answer—they did not return—they went in the direction of Barking Creek—we did not follow them—I saw them go about a quarter of a mile—we got within about twenty yards of them—I was near enough to identify the persons—I saw Daniels, I could not recognise any other person—I saw a quantity of rope and canvas in the boat—it is impossible for me to tell whether it was the same that I saw handed down the companion-ladder—it had the same appearance—they had not an opportunity of getting it out of the boat again—it must have been the same—I did not lose sight of them—I made a state
ment to an officer at Woolwich, I received orders, and went on the Saturday morning to the Royal George revenue-cutter, at Barking Creek, in company with Sergeant Glascock—I searched the cutter, but did not find any rope or canvas—I saw all the prisoners on board the cutter, but whether they were the men who were in the boat, with the exception of Daniels, I cannot say—I left Glascock on board.

JOHN EDWARD GLASCOCK (police-sergeant R 25.) I received information, on Friday night, the 30th of July, from Turner—I took a boat and rowed round the Nymph—a boat had just rowed away from it, with the five prisoners, and another man and a woman in it—I was near enough to it to identify all the prisoners—I have seen them about, and know them all by sight as be
longing to the coast-guard; and Daniels had come to the yard several times—they rowed down the middle of the stream, towards Barking Creek—I ap
proached to within three or four yards of their boat—I hallooed to them, and Angove stood up—I told him to stop, and asked him what they had got in the boat—he said some old stores, which they had been up to Limehouse to get—I saw some rope, similar to that produced, in the stern-sheets of the boat—I did not notice anything else—after I had called to Angove, and he had said that, he sat down, and they pulled away as hard as they could—the next morning I went to the Royal George, at Barking Creek—I obtained leave of the officer in command, and searched her with inspector White—I pulled up a flap and saw a board loose, I pulled it away and saw this canvas—the men were then mustered on board—the prisoners were amongst them, with the exception of Callaghan—the rope and canvas were brought on deck—Williams said he took it for the use of the service, and he did not think there was any harm in taking it—Lieutenant Simpson was the officer in command.

COURT. Q. Did you ascertain, in presence of the four prisoners, that the officer on board knew or did not know of these things being there? A. No; he did not know—he rendered me every assistance—he told me he had drawn no stores at all.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You knew all the prisoners perfectly well? A. Yes; and I dare say they knew me—I have not the least doubt that they would have stopped the boat, only they were a little the worse for liquor—the best part of these things were found in the hold of the vessel.

RICHARD WHITE (police-inspector.) I went on board the Royal George, with Glascock—I assisted in searching, this rope and canvas was found in the hold of the vessel—the hold is covered with a deck—I had the men mustered in the after-cabin—the prisoners were all present but Callaghan—these stores were on the deck—I asked Daniels what account he had to give of the rope and canvas which were found in the hold—he stated that on Friday evening he had been on board the hulk Nymph, that he had been on the deck and walked about twenty minutes, that he neither saw anything put into the boat out of the bulk, or taken out of it, at Barking Creek—I next asked Moon what he had to say—he said he went on board the Nymph to see his brother-in-law, who was boatswain; that he was there twenty mi
nutes, and he did not see anything put into the boat; but when he came into the boat he saw the things in it, and he had lent a hand to put them into the cutter at Barking Creek—Williams and Angove said they were on board the Nymph, and that the boatswain told them they could take as much rope as they wanted, to make swabs; and they took it, and thought there was no harm—swabs are to swab the deck with—the boatswain's name is William Kemmish.

DARIUS PENNIAL (Thames policeman, 25.) I was present on the morn
ing when the Royal George was searched—I searched round about the shore, and found a piece of canvas in a reed-bed, about thirty yards from the ves
sel's side.

WILLIAM KEMMISH. I was officer on board the Nymph, on the 30th of July—I saw Daniels and the other prisoners on board, in the evening—I did not give them leave to take the cordage and canvas from on board.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you not know that they took it? A. I did not—I was in the cabin, and Moon, my brother-in law, was with me—I should say he knew nothing of these being taken, he was in the cabin the whole time with me—I was not on deck at all—I did not see the boat go off—I cannot say where this rope and canvas was taken from—it was not under my charge—I did not see anything of it—I did not know it was on board—I neither looked into the boat when it came nor when it went away—I took no notice of the men going away—I did not come on deck when they went away—my brother-in-law bid me good night, and went away—my wife was with me I have found out since that she went with these men and landlord at the Water-gate—I did not see her off—there was only myself and a boy on board—I told the boy to go and land my wife—I should say these are old stores—I cannot say that they have been dismantled from the Spiteful—I cannot say whether the hold of a vessel is the place where these things are kept.
COURT. Q. Then you were in charge of the vessel, five men came on board of it, and stepped off with your wife, and you made no inquiry about it from beginning to end? A. No.

MR. GODSON. Q. How near was the Spiteful to the Nymph? A. Close along side—it had come from foreign service—when a vessel comes from foreign service there are directions to take the old stores to the dockyard.

COURT. Q. What was done with the contents of the Spiteful when she was dismissed? A. The stores were returned, I believe—the ship was not dismantled, nor the masts and yards—the warrant-officer was in charge of it.
MR. GODSON. Q. What medal is that you bear? A. For service in China—I have been twenty-eight years in the service.
LIEUTENANT SIMPSON. I am officer of the Royal George cutter—on the
morning of the 31st of July some stores were found on board—they did not belong to the Royal George.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had the prisoners been in the service? A. Daniels fifteen years; be always bore a most excellent character—Williams has been eleven years; and the others some years—I have had no complaints against them—it is not usual in the service to exchange things from vessel to vessel—we have received Queen's stores for our vessel, but these we did not receive—these were in the hold, where we always put our stores—there are five hatchways open to it—we have a great quantity of stores; I suppose 200l. worth—this canvas is fit for nothing but to make swabs—if I had seen it lying in the hold as it is, without hearing any account of it, I should have desired my men to work it up for swabs—we had no swabs on board; they were very much wanted—we received our stores two days after this—we get them once in twelve months—I do not exactly know the value of these things—I suppose they would have fetched 15s. or 16s.

MR. PARNELL. Q. What were the wages of these men? A. guines a-week—I believe Daniels has been in the service nearly forty years—there has been no other charge against him while he has been with me, nor before, that I have heard of—if the prisoners had got these stores and wanted to appropriate them to their own use, I think they might have been concealed where no one could have found them.

MR. GODSON. Q. Is not this piece of canvas nearly new? A. I think it is—it would not be used for swabs—I do not know what it would be used for—it seems to be something of hammock-cloth-(the witness here opened it)—it is a cover made to cover a sail—it is nearly new—I suppose it is worth 6d. or 8d. per yard—we do not have our stores from the storehouse, but from private contract—never from the naval stores,

DAVID ROY. I am a clerk in the storekeeper's-office, at Woolwich—I have examined this bundle of rope—it is marked with the worsted thread, the usual mark in the navy—it is worth about 20s.—this canvas is nearly new—it has the Government mark on it, a blue streak of paint in a seperntine form, that is the usual mark in the navy—its value to us would be 10s.—neither the boatswain nor any person at the hulk have authority to pass things from the naval stores to the coast-guard—the coast-guard have their stores by private contact—we have nothing to do with the revenue coast-guard, they are under the Custom-house—they do not have their stores from the naval store.

Cross-examined. Q. In the ordinary course, would not this be passed to the dockyard, as old stores from the Spiteful? A. Yes, and he sold shortly afterwards; but not in this form, it would be cut up—this canvas has been used as awning, or something of that kind—it would be cut up in pieces about two yards long.

COURT. Q. What is the use of cutting it up? A. If it were unservice
able, it would be cut up—it is no use to the dockyard as it is—it has been made, I suppose, for their own convenience.
(Mr. George Wright, Deputy-governor of Newgate, gave all the prisoners, except Moon, good characters.)

DANIELS—
GUILTY.

MOON—
GUILTY.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY.

ANGOVE—
GUILTY.

CALLAGHAN—
GUILTY.

hi.rs:
To enter into recognizances to ap
pear to receive judgment when called upon.

div1.p:
1986.
LEONARD PROVO was indicted
for stealing 18lbs. weight of mustard, value 6s.; and 2 casks, 1s.; the property of
John Green.

WILLIAM SWAISLAND. I am in the service of Mr. John Green, an oil and colourman, at Woolwich. On the 5th of Aug., the prisoner came to the shop—he wanted two casks of mustard, and two gallons of mixed pickles—I gave him them from under the counter—he afterwards said he wanted three bill-heads, which I gave him from off the file—he took one, and wrote on it Mr. Vine's name, what was under it I do not know—he said I was to go with him and receive the money—when I got to the Ordnance Arms, he took the mustard, and told me to go on with the pickles to Mr. Vine, at the Dover Castle—When I got there, the pickles were not ordered.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE Q. Had you known the prisoner previously? A. No—my master is not here—I have been shop-boy there four years—this happened twelve months ago—I do not know whether the prisoner had had dealings there before—I only lost the mustard—I am sure the prisoner is the man—the mustard was in casks, it was worth 2s.—I was not to bring back 8s. and the bottles—I did not hear that—I said I was going with the things—I let the prisoner have the mustard—my master was not at home—the prisoner said he came from the other house to get these things.
COURT. Q. Did you let him have them, because you were to go with him to get the money? A. Yes.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you full authority at this shop to sell articles? A. Yes—I had not to ask my master's permission—if there is nobody in the shop I am allowed to sell things—I am not allowed to trust people.
JAMES VINE. I keep the Dover Castle public-house, at Woolwich. I did not order the prisoner to bring any mustard or casks—Swaisland brought two gallons of pickles—they were not ordered.
Cross-examined. Q. Did your wife order any mustard? A. No.—she was present when the pickles were brought, and the prisoner was left at the Ordnance Arms—I returned the pickles back.
WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman, R 122.) I have been searching for the prisoner, and have not been able to find him for nearly twelve months.

1987.
WILLIAM ASHWORTH was indicted
for embezzlement.

CHARLES STEEL. I am a baker, at Greenwich—the prisoner was in my service—he left me on the 19th of June—he had authority to receive money on my account, and to give an account of it to me every night when he booked his bread—he did not give me 3s. 4d., as received from Mr. Dalton, on the 17th of June, nor 3s. 4d. on the 18th of June, from Mrs. Field—Mr. Dalton pays for his bread every day—I called out the name of Dalton, in booking the bread on the 17th of June, and the prisoner said, "Four loaves"—I asked whether they were paid for—he said, "No"—I asked him again on the 18th, in the same manner—he had to pay 3s. 4d. on the 17th, and 3s. 4d. on the 18th—I did not say anything to him about Mrs. Field, but he has never accounted to me for what he received from her,

Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. What time did the prisoner enter your service? A. The second time, in the middle of May—I paid him his wages every Saturday night, and he had a loaf a day—I discharged him on

Saturday morning, the 19th of June, for getting intoxicated and spoiling my bread—his wages were not paid on that Saturday, and they have not been paid—they would have been on that night—it was 19s.—he has not asked for it.

JOHN DALTON. I am a grocer, and live in the Old Woolwich-road. I dealt with the prosecutor for bread—the prisoner used to come to me daily with it—I paid him 3s. 4d. on the 17th of June, and 3s. 4d. on the 18th of June, for Mr. Steel's bread.

FRANCES FIELD. I am the wife of Alfred Field, of East Greenwich—I dealt with the prosecutor—the prisoner used to bring the bread—he came and received a payment, but I do not know on what day—it was due on the 12th of June, and I paid it on the following week.
Cross-examined. Q. You do not know whether it was the beginning or the latter end? A. No.

GUILTY. Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
confined Three Months

1988.
JOHN DUNN was indicted
for feloniously carnally knowing and abusing
Jane Ringsell, aged 6 years.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Transported for Twenty Years.

1989.
EDWARD LATTER was indicted
for a rape upon
Mary Ann Hitchcock.

GUILTY. of an assault. Aged 49.—
Confined Two Years.

1990.
ANN BLACKMORE was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying a certain male child; also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like offence.

JOHN ROBINSON LEADAM. I am a surgeon, in Tooley-street, Southwark, In July last I was called to see a child of the prisoner's, it was just dead—I ex
amined it—I understood that it had been strangled—there were some crease-marks about the neck, in the situation of the cap-strings, which appeared to have been tied rather tightly, but not sufficient to cause death—I made a post-mortem examination, next day—I discovered nothing particular externally—on removing the scalp I found extravasation of blood on the right side of the head—I immediately examined the scalp, and then observed two or three small bruises on it, very slight, not sufficient to be observed before—I then examined the skull, and found it fractured to the extent of about two inches on the right side—in my opinion, that was sufficient to cause death, it might be caused by a blow, or fall on any hard substance.

prisoner. I am subject to fits.Witness. I do not know her all—I saw her when I was sent for—she was then deeply intoxicated, so as not to know very well what she was doing—she was able to walk—she seemed hardly
conscious of what she was about—she said she did not know the child was dead.

MARY DONOVAN. I am a window, and live in Bull-court—I know the pri
soner. On the 6th of July, about twenty-five minutes past ten at night, I saw her in the yard—she had taken a drop, but was not too far gone then—she was able to walk—she had the child in her arms, holding it round, close to her—I took it out of her arms, and said, "Take care of your child, and yourself too"—she did not seem satisfied to part with it, and I gave it her back again, settled it to her in her arms, and closed the shawl up—she was not holding it in a dangerous way, but the shawl was hanging down, and I settled it about the baby—she then went towards the Bull public-house, and I lost sight of her—I saw her again in about five minutes, going by the thoroughfare that there was—there is a drain there, she missed her footing, and fell down with the baby in her arms—the baby happened to come on its head; it fell under her—I went towards her, she picked herself up imme
diately, and went through the thoroughfare—I heard the child groan after she rose—I did not see her again till the Tuesday morning following.

COURT Q. Was she behaving kindly towards the child at the time you settled it to her, as you say? A. Yes—what I did to the child was out of kindness, and she took it as such—she took the child kindly to her bosom, then walked away, and fell by accident—a sober person might have had just such a fall in the same place, there is no light there—it is an open drain, which a sober person might have fallen over.

1991.
JAMES BRUCE was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Mary Allsworth; he was also charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with the like manslaughter.

ANN DIGWEED. I am the wife of William Digweed, a grocer, of High-street, Lambeth. On Saturday night, the 10th of July, about half-past ten, I was behind the counter—the prisoner came in very tipsy, and staggering—he asked how I did, then turned round from me to the boy Blake, who was sitting on a sugar-tub by the door, and began pulling him about, roughing up his hair on each side, and saying, "You are the chap that serves out the coffee"—he pulled him off the tub, and pushed him against the street-door, he then dragged him back to the counter, then took him round the head with his arm, and the boy being shorter than himself, he had that power over him that he reeled him round and round, and I thought both would have fallen into the street—he took the boy off his feet—they both went out into the street together, and as they went out, they met an old lady, who was stepping on the edge of the path with her supper-beer in her hand, and with one blow they went against her, and knocked her backwards—they were both together at the time the blow was struck—the prisoner had the boy round as he went out of the shop, and went against the old lady—it is a small shop, and the counter is near the door—I could see pretty plainly, there was a lamp alight at a public-house opposite—the old lady turned out to be Mrs. Allsworth, who I knew very well as living four doors off—I saw her fall, with her jug in her hand, as if she had fallen from some high place, she fell direct on the back of her head—I ran out to her, and heard her say, "Oh my head; this will be my death-blow"—I lifted her up, and she was taken home—the pri
soner

went away as far as William-street, which is one door from us, he was afterwards brought back by the boy—Blake said to him, "Come back, and see what you have done; you have knocked the old woman down"—his reply was, "What am I to do? am I to pay for 1/2 oz. of coffee? if I have hurt you, mother, God bless you!" and away he went—he was quite drunk—thinking she was not much hurt, I let him go—I went home with the de
ceased, and saw her bonnet taken off, it was very much dented in at the back—there was no blood—she was still groaning, "Oh, my head"—her daughter laid her on the bed—she died next morning.

Cross-examined by Mr. PAYNE. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A. No, I had never seen him before—when he was roughing up Blake's hair he said, "A little whiting and blue would make you a good colour"—he seemed very foolish, and full of frolic and fun—the prisoner is much taller than Blake—he took hold of him and took him off his feet—when he knocked his head against the door, Blake said, "Now, then," and that was every word he spoke—he appeared to be quite in the prisoner's power when he was whirling round—they appeared to go round and round as if shifted by some machine—when he came back, and said what I have stated, he was mumbling about the boy, and appeared to be saying something about his getting the best of him—I did not hear him say to Blake, "Oh, it is you that rolled me out of the shop?"—Blake was not intoxicated, he was sitting as quiet as a child—the deceased had a bottle in one hand and a jug in the other, I cannot say whether she was sober—the street had been dug up, to repair the water-pipe, a place had been left lower than the other part of the road, and the deceased appeared to fall in that place.

MR. PLATT. Q. The deceased was near that spot? A. Yes, she must have had her foot on the edge of the path, for she spilt some of the beer on the edge of the path, directly opposite—her feet appeared to go just down by the door, and her head into this place that was not repaired—I do not think she stepped from the spot after she was struck.

COURT. Q. You state that the prisoner was drunk, and that what he was doing was in the nature of fun? A. Yes, it would appear like it—what he was doing to the boy was like what a foolish drunken man would intend as fun—it did not appear like an assault or ill-usage, but more in the nature of play—the boy was unusually quiet, according to his character in general—he let him go on, I think, on account of the things in the window, for I called out, "Mind the boxes, do not go through the glass, "

WILLIAM BLAKE. I am twenty years old, and live with Mr. Digweed. I was in the shop on Saturday night, the 10th of July, when the prisoner came in—he first spoke to my mistress, then turned to me, pulled my hair, pulled me off the tub I was sitting on, and pulled me from the door to the counter, and from the counter to the door; he then let go my hair, put his left-hand round my neck, and pulled me outside the door, and when he got me outside, be put both hands on my hair, gave me a pull towards him, and a shove from him—we both went out together round about—he did this against my will—I could not help myself, but I took it in the light of a joke.
COURT. Q. You thought it was the folly of a drunken man? A. Yes, and let him have his humour as he did not hurt me much—I did not care about it, and never intended to complain of it.

p.hi: Mr. Justice Erle being of opinion that the prisoner was not proved to be engaged in any unlawful act at the time the accident occurred, the Jury found him

div1.p:
1992.
HENRY JOSEPH KILLERBY was indicted
for feloniously sending to
Elizabeth Challenor a certain letter, threatening to kill and murder
Elizabeth Spriggs, the daughter of the said Elizabeth Challenor; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH CHALLENOR. I am the wife of John Challenor, and live at No. 45, White-street, Borough. I have a daughter named Elizabeth Spriggs, by a former husband—she is thirteen years old—I know the prisoner—I had occasion to make a complaint of him some time ago, with reference to my daughter—he was imprisoned for a year—he came out of prison on the 26th of Feb., I think—I received the letter in question by post, on the 13th of Aug.—this now produced is it—I had received one previously, on the 20th of July, and one before that—I do not know whose writing they are, but I had many letters before which were proved to be in the prisoner's writing, and I took these to be the same writing—the letters that were the subject of the previous complaint were in the same handwriting.

EDWARD KENDALL (police-sergeant, A 30.) I am acquainted with the prisoner's handwriting—I have seen him write on one occasion—I believe these letters of the 20th of July and the 12th of Aug. to be the prisoner's writing.

COURT. Q. What was it that you saw him write? A. The direction of an envelope and his signature—it was at his father's house, before I appre
hended him on the first occasion—it was done for the purpose of ascertain
ing his handwriting—I did not prove his writing on the first occasion—there was another witness who had seen him write on more occasions, a foreman in an establishment where he worked—he is not here to-day—the Magistrate said it was not necessary, and that I was sufficient—I believe these letters to be in the handwriting of the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. BRIALY. Q. You have never seen him write but once? A. Never, that was merely a direction and his name—it was in Sept., 1845—I requested him to write it, I have got it here—that is all I know of his writing, but I have plenty of writing here which was aworn to as being his, on the former trial.

MR. PAYNE Q. Was it when you went to apprehend him in Sept., 1845, that you got him to write? A. No, some time before, when I was making inquiry to detect the person who had sent the letters—he wrote the direction, "Miss Elizabeth Spriggs" and his own name, in my presence—having seen him write that, I have not the shadow of a doubt of these letters being his—the character of the writing is particular—I paid particular attention to his writing—I went for that purpose.

ELIZABETH CHALLENOR (re-examined.)—The prisoner was apprehended on this charge on the 15th, I think—I have had conversations with him about it—I never spoke to him on the subject of the letter of the 12th of Aug.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you known him for any length of time? A. I never knew him to be the son of Mr. Killerby, till I saw him a year and a half ago—I think he is about nineteen years of ago—I have lived neighbour with his parents for twenty-two years, but never knew him—I do not know of any acquaintance that he had with my daughter—he never spoke to her, not at any period—I have not been in the habit of having any communication

with him, and know nothing of his habits—I never spoke to him till I visited him in consequence of his writing a letter to me about three weeks ago—I thought I would reason with him—he has always been a very close character, apparently, but I know nothing of him—with one exception, I believe he was a quiet, inoffensive person—I have heard that he is fond of reading—we have been extremely annoyed by him for some length of time.

MR. PAYNE Q. You know that he was tried and convicted here in Feb. 1846, for sending a threatening letter to you, for Elizabeth Spriggs? A. I do—I believe my case did not come before the court on that occasion—it was some other case upon which he was convicted—he was not tried upon mine.

The letter was here read, as follows— "Mrs. Spriggs, No.45, White-street, Borough—London, Aug.12th, 1847.—Mrs. Spriggs, —As I have before told you, I am happy to inform you that I know the residence of your daugh
ter Elizabeth, and I can safely promise you, that before another two months has passed away, that your daughter will be in her grave; for as true as there is a God in heaven, I do intend to murder her, and before that time has passed away too, be the consequences what they may. Yours truly, Henry J. Killerby."

DONALD MURRAY (policeman, M 119.) I apprehended the prisoner, on Saturday night, the 14th, on a warrant—I read it to him—it stated that he was to be taken for sending a threatening letter to Elizabeth Spriggs—he said he was very sorry for it, but he had no meaning in it
Cross-examined. Q. Did you hold him out any inducement to say that? A. No.

HARRIET ELIZABETH KILLERBY. I am the prisoner's sister—he will be nineteen in Dec.—he is a very quiet inoffensive boy—he is fond of writing and reading—he reads novels—if he had wished to injure Elizabeth he could have done so very well, for she has been in the habit of coming and sitting in our room with us, and playing with me of an evening, up to the time she went to school—she has not been in our house since my brother came home in Feb.—before he went to prison, she and her sister used to be always with me, and he used to come and sit down and read, and take no notice of any one—she has been about our place, but he never spoke to her—he used to read Lloyd's Miscellany, and those sort of books—he has two large volumes of it, full of such nonsense as this—I have looked into them many times—there are tales about secret conspirators, persons that have made a great noise in the world, love tales, and tales about carrying off young ladies into caverns, but he was quite inoffensive notwithstanding this—he never intended in
juring any one.
MR. PAYNE Q. He was mischievous kind of fellow, was he not? A. I do not know what you mean—he sent poison in three letters to three different young ladies, and was convicted in one case.
MR. BRIARLY Q. Was it ascertained that it was poison that was sent? A. No, I do not know that it was—it was thrown in the fire—it was sent to a Miss Ward.

EDWARD KENDALL (re-examined.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted 23rd Feb., 1846, for attempting to ad
minister poison to Elizabeth Clouter, and confined one year)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person who was so convicted.

GUILTY. Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix. —
Confined One Year

1993.
PATRICK O'BRIEN was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of boots, value 3s.; the goods of
John Booth, from the person of
Thomas Augustus Booth; having been before convicted of felony.

AMELIA BATES. I am nearly eleven years old—I live with my father, James Bates. I recollect going out to play at the Belvidere ruins—I saw John Booth and another little boy there, and the prisoner and a boy a little bigger than him—the prisoner and the other boy took little Booth into a privy, sat him on the seat, and took off his boots—the boy cried—the prisoner said, "If you do not hold your tongue I will take and hit you"—he took out a knife to cut off the child's fingers—I saw the prisoner go away, I caught him—I knew him by sight—the other punched me on the head and got away—I saw the little boy afterwards—he had no boots on.

ANN BOOTH. My husband's name is John—I am the mother of the boy—he went out on Wednesday, to play—he had his boots on—when I saw him in the afternoon he had not got them on—they were my husband's property.

JAMES M'INTOSH (policeman, H 98.) I produce a certificate of the prison
er's former conviction—(read—Convicted Jan. 1847, and confined one month and whipped)—I was present at the trial—he is the boy.

GUILTY. Aged 13.—
Confined Four Months.

1994.
JOSEPH IREDALE,
ALFRED WRIGHT , and
THOMAS BAYLIS , were indicted for
stealing 1 loaf, value 4d.; the goods of
Alexander Hood.

JOHN CARTER. I am in the service of Alexander Hood, baker, of High-street, Clapham. I left my barrow in the middle of the road, not four minutes—I returned, and heard something—I have never missed anything from that day to this—there were sixty-four quartern loaves in the barrow, besides different sorts of small bread—they might have taken half-a-dozen loaves.

HENRY TOOLEY. I live with my father and mother. Between eleven and twelve o'clock I saw Iredale and Wright go up to the barrow and take a loaf out—Baylis waited against a fence—Iredale walked towards Clapham with the loaf—Wright came to Baylis, who stood by the fence.
GEORGE SEARLE (policeman, V 48.) I was called by a constable to assist him—I followed Wright two miles, took him to the station, and found a quantity of bread crumbs in his pocket.
